text: Hands down the best sushi in Chicago!!! I wish we still lived closer because I miss getting their sushi. It was always so fresh and they have this app called the volcano which is amazing!!!
Phenomenal place. Very busy, so everything is fresh. Very friendly people. We keep going back and come almost once s week. Good value

This shop doesn't look like much from the outside, but it's adequate on the inside. The sushi was satisfying. Certainly not the best I've ever had. And average sushi tends to be a turn off for me.  However I can absolutely recommend one roll that was good. The California roll was fantastic. Although that's usually a given at most sushi places.  All in all, don't go out of your way, but if you're near, check it out.

Great 10$ lunch specials ( 3 delicious rolls and soup for 10$). Hidden gem. Very good quality sushi. There are sushi places in Chicago that are better but this is up there as one of the very good ones. Small restaurant - not always easy to grab a seat.

This is by far my favorite sushi spot in Chicago. Although you'd never know it from just looking at the tiny restaurant with about 3 tables, their sushi is delicious!! So fresh and delicious tasting! They have classic rolls as well as fancier interesting ones and they all look like pieces of art. I used to live nearby and am sad I now live outside of their delivery area. They do a big carry out/delivery service as well. Don't sleep on this place! My faves: New York, Chicago Spicy crazy, special california, and spicy salmon!

This restaurant is so good. The fish is super fresh and the rolls are delicious. Lunch set are great deals! For around $10 dollars you get 3 rolls + a soup.  I've put 4 stars instead of 5 because the amount of fish they put in the rolls varies a lot - sometimes I have big rolls, sometimes it's smaller - for the same roll on the menu, so it's a little bit like a lottery.
I love this place. It is our go-to neighborhood sushi spot. The food is consistently delicious and fresh and the staff is always friendly and nice. The prices are reasonable for the quality of food.

The moment I walked in the door, I knew having lunch here was going to be something fantastic! The restaurant itself is very small with six tables and ten counter spots, so we chose to sit at the counter where we could watch the chefs work their magic. The instrumental music was soothing and the decorations added a lot of character, creating a relaxing ambiance. We arrived thirty minutes before lunch service ended and I feared we would be rushed out, but no need to worry; the staff was very accommodating to us and paced the dishes appropriately, which was great because we ordered a lot!! We started with Gomaae and it was so flavorful! It was presented in the shape of a mushroom, and when I cut into it, the vivid warm spinach mixed with the nutty sesame sauce created a smooth blend of sweet and savory. The Ika Masako, squid topped with tobiko, was firm and bubbly; the flying fish eggs popped in my mouth as I happily chewed on the squid slices. The Spicy Tuna Salad was large and creamy with hints of heat and notes of citrus. The sesame seeds sprinkled on top added a delicate crunch.  I picked the steamed Wasabi Shumai dumplings because the combination intrigued me, and it was great! The green wasabi wonton wrappers added spice to the pork filling and there was no need of the delicious side of dipping sauce. The Kani Su salad was a tart and sweet blend of real crab chunks and sliced cucumbers in a rice vinegar sauce. The crab on top was shaped to look like a crab...adorable!  The Baby Octopus was marinated in a fantastic sauce and warmed my soul as much as my stomach. The texture, flavors, and flushed color of the octopus made this my favorite dish. My friend loves salmon, so he chose the Boston Roll, and I thought the simple combination of salmon, crisp lettuce, crunchy cucumber and avocado was clean and delicious. I chose the Caterpillar Roll with  fresh water eel and cucumber wrapped with avocado and it tasted just as great as it looked! For our third Roll, we both said 'Chicago Spicy Crazy' at the same time and it was meant to be! This Roll is Playful and D-E-L-I-C-I-O-U-S The tuna, salmon, white fish and white tuna each had big flavor and the spicy sauce, avocado and cucumber enhanced the proteins. The fiery color of the masago coating was the perfect touch to this STAR of a roll! The Tiger Eyes was a Beauty and reminded me of an M.C.  Escher drawing, an eye within an eye. The knife cuts were clean, the flavors in the smoked salmon were rich and robust, and the sauce in the center of the plate was Devine!  Watching the chefs prepare each dish with such focus and precision made me feel I was in the kitchen of their home, not in a restaurant. I also appreciated the to-go orders packaged in large plastic containers  showcasing the beauty of the rolls instead of cramping them. I will definitely order to-go from here in the future!!

The restaurant is small but a cozy spot to enjoy a nice dinner with your friends, family, or significant. The workers are very polite and the sushi chef are amazing. The rolls are tiny compare to other sushi places I've been to. I would recommend getting the spicy Tuna and shrimp tempura roll. I would come back and cannot wait to. You will end up smell like fry food after coming out of this restaurant.

This place is phenomenal! It's a small mom and pop sushi restaurant (always really busy so come early), everyone is so friendly (and they wear cute Hawaiian shirts). The fish is fresh and to die for. Get the Crunchy and spicy tuna roll and you will not regret it.
I consider myself somewhat of a sushi connoisseur and Green tea is absolutely one of my favorite spots of all time.  Innovative maki and incredibly fresh quality!

Green tea is a hidden gem. It's small, with only a few tables and seats along the bar, but the sushi is well worth a visit. My favorite roll is the crispy roll, or the spider roll. On a cold day, as for a volcano appetizer. It's a spicy creamy sauce over miniature scallops, broiled so its warm and bubbling. Save any leftover sauce to eat with your roll. The chirachi meal is an excellent way to try several types of fish, and the lunch special is an excellent deal. It's not huge on ambiance, and is not good for large groups, but one of my favorite sushi places in the city.

I have no idea why this place got 4 stars. I came here on Tuesday night, the stuffing for the rolls were terrible, not fresh at all (literally tasted like garbage, i think it's spoiled) the rice was mushy and over cooked. I ordered sushi c set and my fiance ordered california rolls. He doesn't know a lot about sushi and even he said the stuffing tastes terrible. So yeah stay away from this place if you don't want to get sick from the spoiled sushi. If i can give less than one star I would. Even my work place(a hospital) had better sushi than this. The only thing that was good was a free green tea that they served.
Great food!!!! I've come all the way from Thailand since I tasted his apprentice sushi, it was great but nothing compared the head chef here!!! Love this place  You've got to try this.

Greentea is one of those neighborhood spots that'd be easy to miss. It has a 6-8 seat sushi bar, and a few other small tables surrounding the bar, for about 20 seats total. The food was ok -- I really liked the Chicago Spicy roll, which had a really interesting blend of flavors. Some of the other rolls didn't have the same freshness/flavor I was looking for.  The service was probably my least favorite aspect of dining here. They seemed to fill takeout orders ahead of dine-in, which we saw from our seats which were close to  the sushi bar. They served rolls as they came out, which was a plus. The prices were also very reasonable, and the place is BYOB. But because of the slow service and average fish quality I probably wouldn't return.

Green Tea is a largely unrecognized and completely surprising gem. Though the number of reviews might suggest that the first part is an inaccurate statement! Every corner of (virtually) every Chicago suburb is populated with "corner sushi" spots. You could not possibly try them all. We "invented" (in quotes to acknowledge that many of you may feel like you "invented" it) the "sushi crawl" to try to address this outage: ride the L, get off at a stop, hit as many corner sushi spots as you can, get back on the L to the next stop, repeat. Sadly, we're too big of pigs to make it last more than 3-4 stops in any ONE neighborhood! So it's kind of an unrefined, maybe failed, concept.  Though, in reality, most such spots are pretty average, some even flat out bad. So maybe that is another reason that the "sushi crawl" might be a failed concept. Green Tea is an exception to this sweeping statement. It is a tiny, unassuming BYOB, seemingly like so many but Green Tea is different. Green Tea is good. Green Tea is damned good. I have today written another (rave) review about an exceptional sushi spot at the other end of the spectrum, Naoki. I would not presume to compare Green Tea to Naoki. They are different beasts and it would not be fair to either to attempt this comparison. However, during our recent foray downtown we had Green Tea for lunch and Naoki for dinner (sushi explosion!) and the latter did not retrospectively color the former in a bad light. Both were very rewarding experiences. I have seen reviews that suggest that "regulars" would prefer that you not know about Green Tea. This is understandable partially because it is tiny, TRULY tiny with a sushi counter that sits maybe 6-8 and maybe 5-6 (small) tables. I guess the PC word is "intimate". So, if "regulars" want to be able to walk in whenever they want and get space (GT takes no reservations), then it makes sense that the rest of us not know about it! For that matter, why am I telling you about it? I want to be able to walk in whenever I want too! So forget that I said anything! It sucks!  However, since the place is small and the staff always looks familiar, I am guessing that this is the way that these people exclusively make their living They clearly work hard and deserve to make a living, a really good one based upon the quality that they offer. So, THAT is the reason to tell you about it! These people deserve to succeed. If that means that I have to wait, or even be turned away, then good for them! As would be expected from this "type" of sushi restaurants, the rolls are prolific, numerous, and featured. However, they are also good. When we go for "sushi" we typically go primarily for sashimi, taking the snob's approach that if you eat rolls, you are not (really) eating sushi, "Oh, pshaw, Miffy...that is what Trad said". This is not fair. Rolls certainly have their place...just typically that "place" is in a "place" where the fish is not good!  We broke with tradition and tried quite a few rolls. We put them to the test trying ingredients that can easily be botched (maybe even make you sick) at lower quality places: oysters, scallops, uni (not that we tried any rolls with the last, just nigiri there). They were all awesome, well-prepared; good, fresh ingredients. While "good" rolls are not necessarily surprising, we were VERY happy with what we tried. Green Tea's rolls are not good, they are exceptional. What was truly surprising was the quality of the fish. In addition to the tour of rolls, we did our typical lineup of our standard 7-9 sashimi cuts. We found the flavor, texture, and temperature quality of each and every cut to be exceptional. This is not always the case at "this type" of restaurant. For example, the "super white" tuna, often called escolar, is very often served partially frozen. Though the entire matter of this ingredient is controversial so let's not visit it further! When so many sushi bars of "this type" fail so monumentally, bringing you big, chain grocery star quality nigiri, how does Green Tea manage to deliver sashimi that is of exceptional quality? We could only come to one conclusion. They must really know what they are doing! They have done it EVERY time that we have visited. While I do not want to wait for my table when I go to Green Tea, go try them and help keep them in business and thriving! People deserve to make a living in this great, albeit currently troubled country of ours. Talented people doing an honest day of hard work REALLY deserve the best. And if you question the sincerity of those stated motives, then just help keep them in business so we can continue to enjoy them for our own selfish, evil reasons! We have NEVER been less than thrilled with a visit to Green Tea Japanese Restaurant!

Solid sushi spot creating some beautifully plated rolls. My only complaint was that the rolls were small for the price, but no doubt they were delicious and made with lots of care- these guys know what they're doing. The restaurant is small and half of the seating is at the bar, which I prefer because you can watch the sushi chefs work their magic. While I loved the dine in experience, this would be a great spot to get take out or delivery, as I watched a lot of orders being made to go.

Wonderful neighborhood sushi spot! Walking distance from the Lincoln Park Zoo.  The spicy salmon salad is a lovely light lunch. Deliciously fresh fish, dressed in a tasty slightly spicy mayo. The rainbow roll was neat and flavorful.  The service is friendly and attentive.  BYOB

Hands down, best sushi in the city of Chicago. Take all your sushi snob friends here, and you'll be their sushi guru for life. You're welcome. Ishmael makes the experience special with his personable welcome and amazing rolls.m The food speaks for itself. Don't go anywhere else. Green Tea has been a family favorite for many years.
It's been awhile since I've been here but when I did go it was great! The spicy tuna was amazing and the food is consistent and great.
Very small inside but we came here for lunch so we didn't have a problem finding a table. I will definitely keep Green Tea as an option the next time I am in Lincoln Park!

Slow. That was a Wednesday night on 8:00. Me and my husband ordered 3 specialty rolls and 6 pieces of sushi. They came after 33 minutes. Yes, I was counting. This place was tiny with no more than 20 seats and they have3 sushi Chiefs. I had no idea what took they so long.  The food was average. Jackie roll was super cute but tasted just ok nothing really hit me. The Chicago love roll was beautiful but tasteless. I kinda got the whole idea of this sushi place, which was that they put more attention on the presentation rather than the art of taste. Unfortunately, I prefer the food itself rather than how the chief present the dish.

Excellent sushi at excellent prices! The unagi roll is delicious, and less than $7. The veggie roles are all $4 or under. A short walk from the Lincoln Park Zoo, making it a great weekend stop for lunch!

Wow, I ate dinner here a few hours ago and am still thinking about how good it was! Sushi is an art here - the dishes were carefully and skillfully crafted.  I got the Jackie roll and it was worth every penny of $15 (10 pieces). The roll was so fresh and the sesame sauce it's served in is delicious. The cucumber salad was perfect (love the toasted sesame sprinkled on top).  It's quite small (and hot) in the restaurant and the rolls took a little longer than expected to come out (about 20 mins) but it was absolutely worth it. I'm already planning my next trip.

came here with two friends on a Tuesday night and it wasn't busy. Saw the great reviews and was so excited to try their food! Service was so-so and they only had one waitress but its a really small place. Really cramped seating. I ordered two rolls for $22. They taste amazing but I still wasnt full. I tried to reorder but the waitress was too busy staring at her phone hiding behind her podium which was right next to me. One of the three sushi chefs saw and got her attention for me. Smh, really?? When i got the check, it was $33 for 3 rolls, one being a very simple one (salmon avo, not on menu) that shouldnt have cost more than $7 because the salmon was $5.75. I still dont know how I was charged that much but i tipped the waitress what I perceived she deserved based on her service. It wasn't too little because we all split checks, but she had the audacity to come back to the table complaining and demanded a higher tip. She wouldnt let me leave unless i tipped her more. Literally standing in my way of getting up and Im a pretty tiny girl. She watched over my shoulder to make sure I tipped enough before moving out of the way so I can leave. Would rather give the sushi chefs the tip....Unbelievable. Never coming back.

Very small place (maybe 20 seats total). Most of the orders are for take out or delivery. It is BYOB with no corkage fee. The Chicago spicy crazy roll and the summer roll was pretty good. Dai Shiroi roll was passable. Not too much flavor in the fried soft shell crab. Service was friendly. Prices were a higher than the norm for certain rolls but place is worth a try.
SCORE! Came down from the burbs, Walked the lake and were craving good sushi. It hit the spot!  Fresh, fast.  Tiny place tho, don't plan on eating in at a busy time.

I am a sushi snob.  The fish needs to be super fresh and the place needs to be super clean!  I was in the neighborhood and thought this place may be a hidden gem as some suggest.  Not some much.  It is an average sushi restaurant with average quality sushi & menu.  I sat at the sushi bar and the guys who were helping me didn't know very much. I asked what fish was the freshest and they told me the lobster.  I laughed & they laughed self consciously  and said I'm sure the lobster is always fresh and then the sushi chef in charge told me the snapper was fresh that day. I could see inside the glass case and some of the fish looked very dry and not so good. I ordered the fried tofu with peanut sauce to start since I was undecided about the fish.  The salmon looked the best so I ordered one salmon sushi and one snapper sushi.  The head chef prepared it as I waited quite a while for both the tofu & sushi order.   Luckily I read it is BYOB and brought a beer to enjoy.   The placed filled up quickly and it was apparent they had a few regulars.  I was hopeful for my food to be tasty.  It was just OK.  The tofu was very hard on the outside, not just brown but actually hard; the peanut sauce had good flavor.  The sushi was OK.  Nothing great.  The snapper was chewy but the salmon was good.   I won't be back because I want better than average sushi, it is raw fish after all.
Pros - Great, fresh susi, sashimi and maki. Cons - The place is small. Overall - Fantastic sushi place.

This place has some of the best sushi in Lincoln park. It's small, yet not extremely well known. Most people tend to stop in for pick ups. It absolutely is the place I choose above toro or nori which surprises most people.
Cute but small sushi restaurant with no corkage fee. Rolls are pretty inexpensive but good. The sashimi platter is also worth it!

I was pleasantly surprised to find a cute japanese restaurant near me.  I came in with a friend after not being too happy about the service and quality of food from another sushi restaurant down the street. I digress, the service was wonderful (water and tea were continuously filled) and the fish seemed decently fresh.  We ordered Chicago Spicy and the Lobster rolls which both were pretty awesome.  The Lobster roll has a bit of wasibi in it which was surprisingly refreshing.  The house salad was a good portion size as well as the yummy volcano scallop appetizer.  I also liked how the mochi wasn't too frozen as I devoured the Red Bean and Green Tea flavors. I am continually exploring the Lincoln Park since I just recently moved here from Tennessee so I will be back for your wonderful service and comfortably cute atmosphere! :)
This place is seriously good and understated. If I had to, I would take an uber clear across town to eat here again.

I really like the sushi here, it's pretty fresh and tasty. The Saba with Ginger is yum and the crawfish is good. The reason it's four is because it's hella small in here. Going to the toilet is kinda annoying too since it's a one person stall and near the kitchen area. Lots of traffic so be careful going back there. It's also a tad pricy.
We order takeout from Greentea all of the time - we prefer brown rice rolls and they have really good ones.

The food is okay. I ordered a chef recommended sashimi and another item on the special, Dai Shiroi. Most of the sashimi was fresh, but one of the fish is not so fresh. I don't really like Dai Shiroi. The fried shrimp is a bit too oily, and the sushi lacks flavor. The service is prompt and friendly. And it's BYOB.

Came here on a Friday night at 7pm. Luckily, there were seats for the 5 of us at the sushi bar so we sat side by side facing the sushi chef. This isn't the place for huge groups. I'd say you should go with 1-2 other people at most.  The server was quick to get us seated. I got to try the sake nigiri (salmon), unagi nigiri (eel), and the nigiri with spicy scallop. They cut you a super thick slice of fish for the nigiri. It was amazing. I've never seen any sushi restaurants give you such a thick slice. They put the thick slice over a small ball of rice. One of use got the uni nigiri...and they give you a huge portion of the uni.  Overall, the food was great. This is more of a place to go to with a friend to chat and catch up or just a casual date. I'd recommend giving this place a try.

Very good sushi place that is BYOB.   I took a visit to Greentea upon a recomendation from my friend. The area is very small, so it would be best for parties smaller than 5.  The server was very friendly and took our orders which were a few of my typical selections: tuna, salmon, and yellowtail.  The sushi chefs were very skillful in cutting our large chucks of fish onto the nigiri and the fish was tasty in terms of Chicago quality. I also really enjoyed their deep-fried oyster rolls, and I saw the Dragon rolls were so neatly created and resembled an animal of sort; something on my bucket list to try next time. Highly recommended sushi place if you are in the Lincoln Park area.
Enjoying the flavor, freshness and hospitality. Straight forward traditional Japanese flavors. No fusion cuisine here. I like it this way.
Oren says its best sushi ever.  I'm not sure about that, but he's got my phone hostage so I'll consent.

My sister took me here for the first time last night and the sushi was amazing! Each sushi and maki dish was 100% on point. Each piece of fish we are tasted was so fresh and smooth. Sushi here is much better than many other places on town that cost more. The seaweed salad was slightly vinegary for my taste, but still delicious.  There is only one waitress who serves dine-in customers, as well as taking care of the take-out orders. And there seems to be a huge take-out business, too. Service is a little slow because of this. They should probably have a second person on staff.  The place is really small so I would recommend going at non peak hours. When we went it was prime dinner time, but thunderstorming, so we didn't have to wait to be seated.  Oh and the place is BYOB! I will definitely be back soon!
This is a hidden gem of a restaurant. Some of the best sushi in Chicago and the price can't be beat. Check out the lunch specials- 10$ for 3 delicious rolls? Best deal in the city.

This is the best sushi in the city. This is where sushi chefs from around the city go to get their sushi. I always get the nigiri and sometimes even sashimi. I think the owner/chef has been there for 15 years or something. Nigiri yellow tail and tuna all the way.
second time trying it. it was not good. spicy tuna was so drenched with mayo i couldn't even taste the tuna.

Small restaurant on Clark that specializes in Sushi. We live near and have tried several of the sushi places around the area and this place serves up the freshest and best we've had. We're starting to go at least once a month. They probably get as many pick-up and to-go orders as dine-in so, it's not crazy busy like other sushi joints on Clark. The staff is nice and professional - seems to be run by a family. Downside is its size, don't expect to get seated together with a more than five party unless you sit on the sushi bar.

Really great sushi... Unfortunately they don't serve saki but the amazing sushi makes up for it. Landed up running down the street and grabbing some saki and brought it back to the restaurant for dinner. Nice staff with very artistic abilities.

I stopped here with four friends after spending the afternoon at Lincoln Park Zoo.  The place was pretty empty when we there but for some reason it took them a while to serve our food.  The sushi itself was mediocre to above average, but the rolls seemed to be cut smaller than in other sushi places I've been to.  If that were it, I'd give this place three stars, but when we received our check, there was an automatic 25 percent gratuity added to our meal despite the fact that we were only a party of five.  The worst part was that we were never informed of this, whether it be by the menu, a sign in the store or by the server.

One of the best Sushi restaurants in Chicago, hands down. Their miso soup is delicious. So far I've had the Rainbow Roll, Sashimi, Lobster Roll and the Daishiroi Maguro. I will definitely visit again, because the Daishiroi Maguro was out of this world. Crunchy and delicious, mmmm!!!

This is an average sushi restaurant; there is not much special about it. If only for that, I would give it a 3/5 stars. However, their service is quite lacking; the whole time, the servers greeted us with a frown. The service was incredibly slow, and we were the only table there! Finally, we were forced to pay a mandatory tip of 23% when our party was only 4 people. We were never informed of this beforehand, which I think is quite ridiculous. I will have my sushi somewhere else now.

After living in Boston for several years we were spoiled by the fresh seafood and excellent sushi there. When we moved to Chicago we struggled to find a sushi place with a comparable quality, that is until we tried Greentea.  We have been there several times and the fish has always been of great quality and very fresh. We usually go for nigiris and rolls and everything has been great.  Most of their rolls are not americanized but they go beyond just the classic/traditional combinations. The baby octopus appetizer is also a must!
My favorite sushi place in Chicago! Tiny little place but the sushi is super fresh and delicious. Great service too - very friendly people.
Absolutely amazing! Super fresh and high quality ingredients. Highly skilled sushi maker. You can get at least $$$quality with $$. Recommend salmon,scallop and salmon  roe.

Delicious food and friendly service. The fish was super fresh and I enjoyed everything I ordered. It was a little pricier than a comparable place in LA, but fish this good can't be easy to get in Chicago. I had a fantastic lunch here.
Just for the price and what you get, it is an awesome little spot . Service is always friendly and sushi is fresh!

my husband & I loved the food. Service is little slow like our appetizers waited on the counter at least 5 minutes. After the server finished her take out order we received our cold appetizers. Oh well they were still good what can I say?  We have our favorite rolls as crunchy roll, spider roll, hashimi roll.  We will go back for sure.
Best japanese food in Chicago. Small family owned restaurant that has true japanese food. The rice is amazing and they always have blue fin tuna specials!

I've lived virtually next door to this place for more than 2 years now and after trying the other sushi places up and down Clark street, I have to say, this has grown to be my favorite (of course, after I realized that it wasn't their food that was causing my stomach issues ;) ). I'm easily here on a weekly basis (except Mondays - I hate that they're closed!!). It definitely is small, and I prefer to eat in the comfort of my own home, so I almost always order carry out. They're always super friendly on the phone and have the order ready in less than 20 minutes. The fish is fresh and delicious; I really like the Rainbow Roll and their sushi is always fresh and flavorful.  The price might startle you a bit ($14 for the Rainbow Roll?!) but I much prefer the quality and friendliness of this place compared to some others down the street, especially Sushi Para II. For me, there's no comparison. Come here and you'll be hooked!

New favorite sushi place...super tiny, modest awesome BYO where they price the vegetable/vegan rolls accordingly. AKA mad reasonable and they have some unique veggie options including the veggie maki which I wasn't crazy about bc I don't love sweet pickles. But their avocado roll was stuffed full of avocado & so was the spinach/sesame. YUM. Everyone else was really happy w/their rolls too...only bummer is no fresh wasabi, the cheeze whiz piped paste wasn't that strong. But, a small price to pay for a great find.
This place is awesome! It's a pretty small location, so I definitely recommend carryout. The sushi is fresh and they have a lot of lunch specials.

I had high expectations after reading the reviews. I was disappointed. The sushi has average price and average flavor. The service is attentive but not very friendly. I wouldn't recommend or come back.

I work nearby so I'm here every other week for lunch and I love it. I'm sticking with four stars instead of 5 just because I have limited experience: I get the same thing every time and I've never been for dinner service.  but the lunch special 'set four' is a great deal and delicious.  the staff is very friendly and kind. not a ton of space for dining in but usually don't have a problem finding seats when going with a couple friends midday

If you want cheap simple great sushi in the Lincoln Park area, this is the place to go. Their fish is better than any other BYOB sushi place I have experienced in the area and their roll selection is much more traditional than most sushi places in the area. i.e. NO deep fried, sour cream on top, cream cheese in the middle, beef-burger wrapped in rice, type rolls. The place is small and feel like a nice neighborhood go-to, so if you have a group of 12 and are expecting to do sake bombs all night while taking sporadic trips to the bathroom to throw-up, please go somewhere else. Like a different city. In a different country.  A voluminous meal for two will set you back about $40-$50 including tip so this is definitely an affordable option to add to your list.
High quality fish, good value and casual.  Place is small but does a lot of take out orders.

Green Tea is a small little sushi restaurant that delivers amazing rolls and a fresh taste. I loved their creative rolls and artistic presentation - one of the best I've come across. Their fish is also fresh and the rolls themselves are filling. Green Tea definitely does not skimp on any ingredients in their sushi, so that was a huge plus. I also really appreciated the lovely art that the sushi chefs incorporates onto the plating. It's the art that really makes Green Tea the place it is. Overall, I really enjoyed my experience at Green Tea. I sat at the bar with my friends, which could be a little cramped space-wise, but didn't bother me too much. You really can't go wrong with ordering any of their special rolls. I especially liked the Caterpillar roll and Summer roll. So much deliciousness! Service was great, but the wait for a table might be long if you come during rush hour times. There aren't many tables inside the shop itself, so be prepared to be patient. This little sushi joint in Lincoln Park is a must-try.

This place is very unassuming from the outside, and the seating is limited to the bar and a few tables, but the food is excellent. I've been here a few times, and I'm always impressed by the freshness of the fish and the flavor profiles they put together, from the special rolls to the spicy tuna/salmon salads, and the size of the rolls is quite good as well! Prices are reasonable, especially the lunch specials on weekdays. As far as the special rolls, you're in for a treat if you order the Dai Shiroi Maguro (white tuna over shrimp tempura/avocado/cucumber inside), and if you're after a lot of fish, give the Chicago Spicy Crazy roll a try. The shrimp tempura here has a lot more flavor in the batter than most. Very consistent, high quality, and I will be back again.

Don't let the modest store front fool you, this is the best sushi place I've been to in Chicago. Been here twice and will definitely be back. Super fresh tasting, reasonably priced, and byob. My favorite is always a dragon roll, and their's is to die for. The presentation is outstanding as well. The service was very friendly and attentive both times I've visited. BYOB which is always nice.  I guess the only down fall is the limited seating and it's probably no good for parties larger than four people. Although I do have to say that the tiny size does make it feel very intimate and special. Gotta be one of my favorite overall places to eat in the city.

Best and most fresh sushi place I have found in Lincoln Park. This was actually the very first place I tried sushi after moving to Chicago 15 years ago. I highly recommend this place as every roll is so delicious and fresh! Place is also byob but is very small and can get pretty crowded. I will be a life long patron of this hidden little gem for as long as I live in Chicago!

I had awfully high expectations for Greentea given these rave reviews on Yelp.  Both my experiences at Greentea were very marginal at best.  On both visits (the first dine-in and second takeout), the unagi, maguro, and salmon were good and fresh.  Every other cut wasn't as stellar on the freshness department.  One my last visit, I made the mistake of ordering red snapper and halibut.  Both had a nasty smell that I opted not to eat them since I didn't want to risk getting sick.  The rice was also overcooked on both occasions.   Service was acceptable on both visits, but not as great as other Yelpers have experienced.  I was a little grossed out by the server sneezing and not washing her hands on my last visit as I was waiting for my takeout order.  It's a bummer that Greentea hasn't delivered a great sushi meal because it's so conveniently located to my place.  I really wanted to love this place!

I have been finding the authentic japanese restaurants in Chicago. Greentea is one of them. We were seated at the rustic wood table by the cute staff. We started off with Gomae, it was totally different from the other japanese (fusion) restaurants. If you are japanese fans , must try!! Then we ordered Volcano....SUPER tasty- the right amount of heat combined with amazing sauce and scallop. We also ordered some Sashimi, all of which were beautifully prepared by professional head chef. For Sushi roll we had Crunchy... the best warmed roll I've never had, no tempura flour!! no bread crumb as the other restaurants usually do. The second roll, we ordered Jackie .... so cute!!!!! If anybody doesn't like any raw fish, I'll recommend this adorable roll (Shrimp tempura inside with cooked shrimp on top) LOVE It!!! Well..another roll was Winter ..incredible as well!!! like the chef really paid attention to each part of this roll.  In addition, they have unique RICE ever. You know right?? ... "Fish is the same as fish in any restaurant..so the rice is more important then.  Moreover, the take out presentation was immaculate too. Other reasons why I gave 5s to them aside from their food are ... reasonable price, neat place, friendly staff and you can ask any questions with the head chef individually!!!!!!!

One of the very best Sushi places in all of Chicago. As a matter fact, I do plenty of traveling for my job and I've tried many sushi places all over the country. This ranks at or near the very top of the best sushi place in the country. It's all very fresh and the service is top notch. You get plenty of "bang for your buck" in a small intimate setting.

Hands-down, this place has the best sushi I've ever had anywhere. There's no ambiance in the restaurant to speak of, but if you're looking to enjoy high quality sushi, this is the place to go. Plus, it's BYOB.

This place is fantastic. It's consistently good. The sushi is so fresh. The pieces of sashimi are huge and very fresh too. Byob which is awesome. It's pretty small and always crowded. That's how you know it's good.

Obsessed! The sushi here is fresh, well prepared and delicious. On top of that, the chefs and waitress are super friendly and the service is great. The quality of the sushi far exceeds the price you pay too. This place is a gem! My husband and I are big nigiri eaters, so the freshness of the fish is really important to us. Greentea never ever disappoints.

This place is consistently good.  Every time I go, I love it.  It is cheap and beats most of the sushi places that cost more.  You don't go for the ambiance, you go for the food.  Real little place.  Crunchy Roll, New York, and Dai Shiro are all amazing.  Crunchy Roll is never shared.

Overall: A great spot for an easy lunch or dinner with decent sushi and a friendly atmosphere. Nothing fancy, but sometimes casual sushi is all you need! The good: Low prices, great lunch specials, friendly and fast service. The sushi isn't the best of quality, but it was fast and efficient and got the job done. Lots of menu options. Food came out really quickly. The play decent music compared to some that play top 40. The bad: Small restaurant, obviously you get what you pay for quality-wise. It's not amazing sushi, but it's still good.  Atmosphere: 7.5/10 Service: 8/10 Food: 7/10
They DO have miso soup, you just have to ask!! Still one of the best low key sushi spots in LP. Love love.

Went late on Sat. night . Sat at the bar with gf and our drinks of the eve .  It is a Byob,which makes it that much better. Amazing specialty roll that was fresh smoked salmon. This was incredible and they even gave the extra salmon that was glazed in a delicious sauce. Spider roll was quite good .  No frills and super small, but such freshness and easy on the wallet.

Best spicy tuna roll in the world! Confirmed by all of my friends I have taken here over the years. Very inexpensive. Sushi is always fresh. Friendly staff. BYOB.  Get the spicy tuna roll or hand roll. You will not regret it. Volcano appetizer is also amazing.
Simple, Super fresh, really tasty.Basically exactly what sushi should be.
I love this place. They need to open more locations! Dragon, volcano, crunch roll... Just pure yum.  Best in country!!!!  *atmosphere and bathroom need help.

Awesome Sushi Pieces and rolls.  Probably the biggest Sushi Piece cuts in the Shire.  Ambiance is small and just ok.  But if you are coming for Sushi with decent pricing and (cut cuts) it beats Kamahachi my go to place Pan Down!
Yum! sushi just melts in your mouth and the prices are great.

It looks like they changed the waitress. This place used to be a very good place to go.  The food are good and the waitress is very friendly. Recently I brought my relatives to have a dinner in there, the waitress is a new one.  She is not very nice.  Her service is not great.  At the end, she automatically charged me 20% tips and also ask for additional tips.  I felt not happy about it. Last week I ordered some food through the phone, my kid went there to pick it up. She forgot to put the order in.  Finally it took 1 and half hour to get our order. The dragon roller doesn't look good like before. It seems new owner and new waitress. I will never go back to this place any more.   June
Amazing quality and selection. Even the fried rolls tasted fresh. A tasty and creative experience. Service was fantastic as well.

Green tea sushi is by far the best sushi in Chicago. It's authenticity, quality grade fish, and service make this place more appealing to me than Nori Sushi, all of the Sushi Para places and even over priced Japanois.  The spicy shrimp tempura roll melts in your mouth.

Love this sushi restaurant. I visit Chicago and always make a point to come to Lincoln Park and eat here. One of my favorite sushi restaurants. Owner, head chef, will make anything you want. Always pleasant service and fresh food. I could eat here all the time. I do dream about my next trip to Chicago so I can have the "crunchy roll." Yum!

The other sushi place had an hour plus wait, so we yelped for the next best thing-- Greentea! We both ordered the sashimi C platter.  I would say the quality was moderately fresh at best. If you're going to order any sashimi, just get salmon. Otherwise I'd just stick with the rolls.

SOLID. That's the perfect word for this place.  This unassuming and small sushi spot in Lincoln Park proves that you don't have to be fancy schmancy to serve good food. Their nigiri servings are generous and the rolls are delicious. The place is small. It will probably seat at most 25 to 30 people and they usually only have one server.  Although it's probably not the best place to bring a first date to because of the decor, it's a good place to bring someone you don't need to impress (in a good way... if that makes any sense). The place is very down-to-earth and very affordable considering the portion sizes and quality of the food. All in all, it's a great sushi place for someone in a budget!

Hole in the wall Japanese wonderland. The prices are good, the service is efficient, and the food is delicious. If you want authentic Japanese food at good prices, you need to be here. You can sit at the bar and watch the experienced chefs cut up the fish, or you can grab a cosy table. It's BYOB.  I've tried the rice bowl with plenty of raw fish, various sashimi, the salmon salad (with scallions), and some of their rolls. Easily my favorite sushi place in Chicago. It feels like you are in Japan, until you step out right into the heart of Lincoln Park.  I completely recommend it!

I think I should start reading more about a restaurant on yelp other than how many stars they got and what their highlight dishes are. "Whether it's good for groups", for example, would have been useful information prior to us coming to this place for a birthday dinner in a group of 6. This place is equipped with 10 table seats and maybe 6 bar seats. We waited for more than half an hour for three tables to finally free up. NBD, the food made up for it - {Rolls} We got six rolls - Chicago spicy crazy, summer, crunchy, lobster, veggie, and rainbow. The only thing that left a lasting impression on me was Chicago spicy crazy, which had generous servings of fish. The summer roll was tasty too. Overall the rolls are smaller than what I usually pay for but again prices are very reasonable for the location. Their fish was very soft and so were the rolls - but they were not falling apart so I did not mind it.  {Apps} The sauce that came with the shumai was not at all authentic, per our Japanese friend. The shumai was tiny but it did come in 5 pieces. Fried tofu tasted very much like fried bread - maybe they freeze the tofu first? Interesting texture, sauce was good and the serving was generous. We did not get to try their sashimi or nigiri but based on the reviews and my experience, their fish was decent quality. I will definitely order take-out/pick-up from this place.

Just went to Greentea last night for the first time. Originally we planned on going to Toro but it was closed...even though there were people inside assuming employees.  Anyways, back to Greentea. My man loved that it was byob. We made a stop at Binny's to grab him some Asahi. We shared the edamame and we both had miso soup which was really good. On to the sushi, I had the spider, dragon, and california. I love the fact that the server made sure there wasn't any fish eggs on them because I was pregnant without me asking her - shows you how attentive she is. My man had the spicy california, spricy tuna, and spicy salmon. We both enjoyed our makis and we were definitely stuffed by the end of dinner. We'd like to come again if we're ever in the LP neighborhood.

I've tried almost every BYOB sushi location between Clark and Diversey, Green Tea is the real deal. Reasonably priced, quaint space, fresh fish, this place is great. They do mostly takeout, there are roughly 6 tables inside. On off hours, I've been able to score a table, but it's easier to pick-up. I enjoy their spicy scallop, shitaki mushroom, gyoza, even their seaweed salad is great. Greentea is unpretentious, well-priced, and high quality for what you pay. I would definitely recommend it!
Like many other reviews... this is our go-to. Everyone has their around the corner/ neighborhood sushi joint... and this is ours. It is small but sushi is great.

I have tried close to 80% of the sushi places on the north side of Chicago. Some I go to for ambiance, some for services and convenience, and some for just great sushi. This place is NO frills, amazing sushi I would say best I have had in Chicago, and simple.  Its very small, no ambiance but still very delightful, and the service is ok.  If I had to say it lacks in service. But the sushi makes  up for it.  Its so fresh and very reasonably priced.  I would say if you want just good fresh sushi at a good price check it out.  Much better than Toro down the street!

THE BEST SUSHI/SASHIMI YOU'LL EVER FIND. If you love raw fish this is the place to go. We usually the get Sashimi A and a couple of rolls. Every single piece of sashimi is so fresh, and you can really taste the flavor of each piece. The california rolls are the best I've ever had. They use real crabmeat which makes it SO GOOD. I've gotten appetizers there, and every single dish is made well. The sushi chefs are pros, prices are fair, service is great. It's a small place but there's a nice atmosphere, and everyone at the restaurant including the sushi chefs are so friendly. Highly recommended. I go every time I'm in the area.
Love the sushi! Love the boss! Such great service. I get Green Tea at least 3-4 days weekly for lunch. My new fave are the Winter roll & Unagi Don with brown rice.

This has been my go-to sushi place since I discovered it on Yelp a few years ago. The dining room is approximately the size of a walk-in closet, but the food is good and the seafood is fresh. Having relatives who work in the seafood business, I get irrationally pissed off when I look at the sushi prices at most restaurants. I know a bowl of delicious seaweed is not worth $20. That being said,  Greentea is very fairly priced for its excellent quality. And that's not even factoring in the technical skills of the chefs!  I've never tried the sashimi (not a fan of it in general), but I've tried most of the sushi offerings and no duds have turned up. My favorite appetizer is the volcano, especially in the winter. Service is good, but then again there are only four tables and a bar fitting 6-ish people to look after. A meal for two has been anywhere from $30-$60, depending on hunger levels.  Street parking is a mixed bag, as it usually is. I'm still subconsciously on the lookout for the Hummer that stopped in the tow zone in front of my car and decided to open its trunk door into my hood. By the time I got out of the restaurant to see the the delightful dent, the Hummer was gone and none of the surrounding security cameras caught its plates. But I digress. Lines can be long on some nights because of the aforementioned closet-sized dining space, but it is well worth a try.

Finally - I've found a low key sushi spot near my place that is affordable yet has quality fish!! The layout is very modest, they are BYOB, and the sushi chef's are professionals. We had the spider roll, caterpillar roll, unagi nigiri, and toro - each was better than the last piece. Highly recommend this place - I'll be back many times to come!

I've been here several times, and honestly think the sushi is fantastic. I've never gone wrong with the spider roll, spicy tempura roll, or the Sashimi Appetizer. The fish is sooooo fresh and honestly, you cannot find a better value for the price. Plus it's BYOB and the delivery is reasonably priced if you want to go that route. It's a tiny venue, so plan accordingly. It's worth the wait though!

I can't tell you how much I love this place. If I could eat here every day, I would. The head sushi chef always says "see you tomorrow" as you leave, so cute, and I always think... i wish! The sushi is so fresh here, amazingly priced, and they have nice variety. I love the spicy salmon roll and the new york roll, both my favorites! The chicago spicy crazy is a huge roll and totally worth the price. This place is a gem!!
Great little place, good atmosphere and solid food. The Chicago Crazy Spicy roll is fantastic, as is the Summer Roll. Also had the best Rainbow Roll I've had in a while! Highly suggest it.

I guess it's time to update this review because this place still works for me. Like most small sushi places, it's first come, first serve on weekend nights. Waiting isn't that terrible, but I guess it really depends on the time of night. On a recent visit, I tried a spinach roll and an avocado roll (both separate rolls) in addition to my regular order, the crunchy salmon roll. My friend also got an order of fried tofu and a vegetarian roll of which she enjoyed. We couldn't have picked better rolls that night - much needed sushi dinner. Plus, all that was about $28. Not bad, right? It also helps that it's BYOB here (Note to self: why don't I come back often!). Our server brought us an ice bucket to help keep our second bottle (white) cool though we didn't even drink it. I guess there's always next time.
The best sushi i had period. I have been to Coast Sushi,Niu,Japonais and others i truly believe this one is the best.

Stumbled upon this place while looking for sushi in the Lincoln Park area and I'm really happy I did. The sushi is very good. The restaurant in small but cozy and prices are reasonable. Definitely going back.

This is a great date place. A lot of people have lamented the small size, but that is my favorite part. Sitting at the sushi bar and watching the chefs work is so much fun. Yes, it's small and there can be a wait on a Saturday at 8, but my solution is to not go saturdays at 8.  The fish here is just so good. We've tried several of the very fancy rolls, and while they are fancy and delicious and popular (dragon roll comes to mind, which it seemed that everyone in the place had while we were there), to me the real standout is the sushi. The fish is so good that it just seemed wasted to me to bury it in the giant sauce covered roll! I've really loved any of the sushi and the simpler rolls.  The fish is really fresh, and I don't really know enough about sushi to know why it's so good, but it just is, trust me.  Probably my current favorite non-sceney date place for sure.

I have been coming here for years and it is hands down my absolute FAVORITE sushi (and restaurant overall). Their ingredients are super fresh and tasty, the staff is incredibly sweet and great at their job and it is so reasonably priced on top of all of that!
Husband said best sashimi ever. Lovely service, super salmon  fish meal. Small hole in the wall with Terrific food...and delightful table service. BBYO

Great quality and price. Their sushi is always delicious and fresh, and the best part is that is cheap compared to other places. We are regulars, since its conveniently close to home and we love to do take out. It is a bit small to dine in, but really good.

Ick. Seriously Yelpers...you definitely got this one wrong. Rolls were not good, bland and not inventive in the slightest.  I went here last night with a friend and while she was more on the fence than I, she agreed that she would not likely dine there again. The place is super small and clearly do most of their business on carryout - yes somehow I feel like that would be even worse. We had a few of their specialty rolls such as the Lobster and a spicey Tuna combo crunch roll (can't remember the name). Both were nothing to write home about.  Greentea - Next time you need to try a little harder to win over a die-hard sushi-lover. Too bad you had your chance...we were the only ones in there!
Affordable and great sushi near my neighborhood. DaiShiroi roll (under special roll) is a must! Friendly ppl but uncomfortable to dine in.

Greentea is right around the corner from my house, so I stop by on my way home often. The fish is very fresh and consistently so. Sevice is great, everyone is really friendly, all the time. The place is very small, but that is perfect for a sushi joint. Every piece of fish I have had has been good, one of my favorite rolls is the crunchy roll, try it. The vegetarian rolls are not the best, I have tried many and not liked them except for the avacado roll, which is delicious. Stick with the fish and you will leave with a smile on your face.
I'm lucky to live just around the corner from one of the best sushi places in Chicago. Sushi and rolls are always fresh and super tasty.

My favorite Sushi place in Chicago. It helps that it is just a block away from my apartment but if it was across town I would still make the trip to this place. I have been coming here for years. Its fantastic and the prices are great. You can be full on less than $20 easily. The fish is so fresh and the rolls are creative and delicious. The staff is so friendly. They are always so nice and welcoming. Tonight when I was leaving the restaurant and it was pouring down rain the owner's wife walked outside after they were closed to offer my friend and I an umbrella.  Fresh Fish, Great Service, Well Priced. You can't beat it!

This is my favorite neighborhood sushi place in all the world. In addition to being cheap, conveniently located on the 22, and delicious, it has the following amazing characteristics: - BYOB (but prep in advance, nearest liquor store is a few blocks away) - Best California roll ever. No seriously! The snow crab they use is incredible and this is still my standout fave after years and years. - Delicious spicy tuna roll, since they slice and mix the tuna to order (no days-old mix) - Super sunny with big windows to Clark St. - Extra friendly chefs - who shout "see you tomorrow!" each time someone leaves. So cute. The restroom is behind the sushi bar toward the kitchen, and there are only a few tables, but this is part of the experience.  I love you Green Tea. Never change!

I live 1 block away; Greentea is the closest sushi place to my house.  I've been coming here for 2 years, as a point of reference.  It's very unfortunate that I've got to write this review, but people gots to know.  This USED to be a fantastic little gem, with fantastic value.  I was excited to live so close to a sushi joint that had reasonable prices, and good, quality fish. Greentea is no longer worth going to, especially with the myriad of other options you've got on Clark.  I'm not really into the "super imaginative maki," scene. I like eating fish, and I like the fish to mostly speak for itself.  If you happen to be into the really overblown maki, this place will not knock your socks off.   Ah, the Sashimi Platter.  The ONLY gauge, in my opinion, of the quality of a sushi place.  If an establishment whose job it is to serve raw fish to the public can't manage to serve that shit fresh, then they should burn the place down and collect insurance money.   I waited to write this review until I went back after the first bad experience I had a month ago. It happened again. I had the most disgusting piece of rancid fish as a part of my sashimi platter -- 2 times in a row now.  I'll spare you the details of what happened when I put this in my mouth, but it was not good.  Imagine eating a 3 day old washed up Asian Carp that you found at North Ave. Beach   Want to eat sushi on Clark? Go somewhere else.  Ponzu or Toro are great options.

Finally - a place that doesn't charge "Chicago" prices for good sushi! Hiyatushi! I don't speak Japanese and don't know that Hiyatushi is a word. I wanted to express my excitement. The rolls are decently priced, and the signature rolls are reasonable as well. We got our sushi in a reasonable amount of time and the service was very friendly. The only issue is there are not many tables, so expect to wait a little bit unless you want to sit at the sushi bar. Hiyatushi, everyone!

I LOVE this place. I try not to tell too many people about it because I don't want it to get over-popular, especially when it is small. It's kind of a hole-in-the-wall type of place where you eat just sushi, and unique sushi at that. It is also very affordable. Try their special rolls like the crunchy roll, which is unique. I also love that their spider roll and other rolls for that matter aren't "filled" with california roll ingredients like other sushi places. It's so great!

amazing quality fish at a great price! this is my number one spot for nigiri (salmon and tuna mmmm)! i wasnt too impressed with the rolls but only because they were incredibly warm. i dont think ive ever had rolls this warm but they were still delicious! love this place!

For some reason I've been conditioned to the hip sushi joints of Wicker Park that when I came to Greentea I was actually taken aback by how cheap and unpretentious it is here. The sushi was really good, and I tried raw sea urchin for the first time. Tastes like the sea farted or something. Not a fan, but I did experience satisfaction as a diver, being able to get back at these sea urchins. Huh? This is a great, solid neighborhood place. If I lived in the neighborhood I could see coming here regularly.

Tried this place based on the strength of Yelp reviews. Tried a few nigiri and a few rolls. We thought the salmon was fresh but the tuna and toro were both pretty bad -- flavorless and tough/stringy. The Daishiroi Maguro roll was actually pretty good, but I thought the Chicago Spicy Crazy roll was mediocre at best. My dining companion did like the lobster roll, I was unimpressed. Overall I would not return due to the low quality tuna.

No thrill ambiance, but extremely satisfying food. End up going here after finding out Pizza and Oven Grinder was not open for lunch. A Yelp search show that this 4 stars restaurant was across the street. So wife and I took a chance, even though we normally do not eat sushi. Best last minute decision we made. Would recommend those who never had sushi to stop here first. When the waitress brought our entrees, we almost did not want to eat it, since it look like art work. I had Sushi A (5 piece sushi, 4 piece special california , 4 piece kappa maki) and wife had Salmon Don (sliced fresh salmon on sushi rice). As mentioned, not a sushi person, so not going to try to describe the flavors I experience. Just understand from a newbie perspective, sushi was excellent and service was wonderful.
Probaly the best tuna roll I've ever had, very fresh,the scallop roll , veggie roll and shrimp tempura roll was very tasty as well....

Quaint. I was a huge fan of this place before I tried Toro (but I still like it!). It's a great alternative: less of a wait, a bit smaller, fish is fresh and rolls are great! Good little girls night spot or date joint. BYOB AND great service. Beware, no reservations so just hop in if you see an empty table, or go the store across the street to buy your booze while you wait.

Great food. This is quality stuff at prices that make a complete sushi meal.The price "Sushi" is as good as in other more expensive restaurants  but it is much cheaper here.  The food was fresh - every dish was to die for.LOL! The chefs are very friendly too and so is the staff, it tends to get very very crowded, so takeout is advisable if you can't wait for vacant seats. Love it and will definitely go back as often as possible - easily the best food in Chicago.

It's a very small and cozy place with lots of nice maneko nekos.  It has a good vibe. We tasted some rolls and sashimi, they were really fresh and well done. My favorite was the rainbow roll, it's a very creative mix of sushi rolls.  I would love to come back.  The GreenTea deserves **** because it's a good value for money.

Okay, full disclosure, I haven't been to many sushi places in the city.  That being said, sushi is my all-time favorite food, and Green Tea is my all-time favorite place to get sushi. Whether you're sitting at the bar or at a table, the atmosphere is great.  It's small, intimate, and most importantly delicious!  I always order one of the specials along with my regular choices because it never fails to disappoint.  The prices are average for sushi, and BYOB with no corkage fee makes this a great date night restaurant.

Great quality, fresh and cheap sushi! It's also BYOB. We tried many different dishes and they were all good. Highlights on top of my head: Chirashi, winter roll, dragon roll, Octopus salad.  we had toro by piece. it was not as fatty as i expected it to be. that's the only con I can find.  They don't take reservation. We went there Sat night at 7 pm and there was no wait. We got the table right away (more on the lucky). At about 7.15-7.30 pm, the line started building up. There will always be 5-6 queues ahead of you. The place is really small. They can probably take 4-5 tables at mac and couple more seats at the sushi bar area. There were lines until we left at about 9 pm. So, you need to plan your timing well for this great & reasonable price sushi!

Best sushi in Chicago - that is if you love the taste of fresh fish better than cream cheese-chipotle tempura rolls, or that sort. Fantastic saba, hamachi and uni. The prices are so modest, it makes you want to cry.. with joy . I recommend Sushi C. It actually includes uni... BTW, reviewing a sushi restaurant based on the quality of its spicy tuna roll is like reviewing a steak house based on its burgers.

Sushi without the "scene". Because sometimes you just want sushi without the "vibe". GT is perfect for that. GT is small, only 6 seats at the sushi bar and 4 tables-- 2 tables that seat 2, and 2 tables that seat 4.  Very casual sushi spot.  Service is friendly. And you can't go wrong with BYOB!  They do a brisk carryout service too, but that didn't delay our order at all.  For a Saturday night at 8, only the tables were taken, so the hubs and I took to the sushi bar. We split an appetizer, a sushi special and 2 maki rolls. The price was very reasonable and we left very satisfied.  The Wasabi Shumai appetizer was good in flavor, but a little too mushy for my taste.   The rice in the nigiri and maki was perfect.  The fish was very fresh and good quality. For some folks, a California roll may be on the "mundane" side, but I love 'em and the California roll here was the best I've had in long time. They used real crab and not the imitation crabstick. The Crunchy Roll (spicy salmon wrapped with tempura batter) was definitely crunchy and tasty, just not that spicy. The Daishiroi Maguro roll (seared super white tuna with shrimp tempura and cucumber, garnished with tobiko) was definitely my favorite. Great flavor and super fresh. The nigiri pieces were good portion size and not too tiny at all.

We love coming here and ordering carry out.  Always fresh reasonably priced and great byob service.  You can probably find a handful of sushi restaurants that are more inovative but you can't find a better all around every week spot

OK....  - so the scrumtous photos on here got me. It truly looked amazing. Smaller dining area than I expected. Warning:  They are VERY UPTIGHT here.  For some strange reason...the sushi chef's are not permitted to speak with the patrons at the sushi bar!!!! Not kidding here folks!! Additonally, the sushi chefs are not allowed to simply "hand" over the food if you are sitting at the sushi bar!!  They call the waitress...hand her the food...then she hand's it to the sushi bar customer - whatever. ABOUT the sushi - VERY AVERAGE.   - BUT - I have to mention something about the spice tuna and spicy salmon. We ordered spicy tuna and spicy salmon hand rolls.  They have the spicy tuna and salmon "pre-mixed" and it is somewhat slimey and very chopped up - not whole pieces - having had sushi from New York to L.A. - I've really never seen just tid- bits like this before.  So....if you like impersonal service, no music, no beer or sake menu, and you like to fill up on hand rolls....by all means - avoid this place like the plague.

There are several things to love about Greentea: it's a BYOB, they are friendly, the price is right. But, there are also a few things not to love about Greentea: I kept getting a faint whiff of something that was quite like sewage, service was a little flaky, it's the size of a large walk in closet.  The restaurant design and the food presentation is average. Nothing special. The food was kind of hit and miss. The goma-ae (boiled spinach) was awful. The wasabi shumai was okay (better with soy than with the accompanying sauce). The maki rolls were good.  In fairness, my experience was probably closer to a 3-1/2 star meal but it was definitely not a 4 star dinner. I might come again after reading some of the reviews and getting a better idea of the food items that are consistently good.

Greentea is one of my favorite sushi places!  For seasoned sushi veterans They will even deep-fry the sweet shrimp head for you. If you are looking to unload some cash for incredible visual displays made out of sushi with lots of different sauces and flavorings, look elsewhere!  The approach here is a little more traditional.   The dining area is small so you may have to wait for a table.  Lunch specials are an excellent value. Greentea is BYOB!  "See you tomorrow!"

I was impressed!  Very impressed!   Going in, I was skeptical because I was invited by my white friend, and, as a general rule, I don't take recommendations for Asian food from white people.  Also, the staff are all Thai.  However, I think this place a great! First of all, the decor is sooooo typically Japanese; I really felt like I was in a small Harajuku or Shibuya restaurant.  You'll see when you go; it's just so Japanese! Secondly, and more importantly, the food is just excellent.  I just order a sushi platter and a sashimi platter if it's just two people. Also, this place is BYOB, so bring your own Saki.  I usually go after 8:30 on a Friday or Saturday night, and can get a table easily.  But don't go at the peak hour, because they do not take reservation.

I hope I don't get sick!  I live across the street from Green Tea, and just got carry out.  After waiting 20 minutes longer then my quoted time, I got out and everything was at room temperature.  The sauces and the fish were all room temp, which leads me to wonder what temperature they are holding their raw fish at.  Also, the two rolls I got had "spicy" but didn't have any sort of flavor at all.  One had a "spicy sauce" on top that tasted like warm mayo.  gross! I really wanted this to be as good as everyone else has said, but , I just can't take the chance of getting sick.

Came to this place out of a recommendation of a friend. The sushi here is of quality. And you definitely get more for the price. In fact the portions here are a bit bigger than most sushi restaurants.  The downside is that the place is small, so I usually go for take out and parking is a challenge. With that said, if you are a local, this is definitely the place to go, but if you are a tourist or you have a group, I suggest going somewhere else.

The food here is amazing.  I have been a customer for over 5 years and have never had a bad experiance.  Try the spicy tuna roll and the crunchy roll.   The prices are also great and they are family owned and operated.  Sometimes when I go there for lunch (when there prices are even lower) and I feel bad because I am paying under $12 for a full out sushi lunch. Wh

Greentea offers decent sushi for modest prices, and may become my go-to sushi place from now on. My companion and I got there a little early on a Thursday night, and had no wait. It's a small room with only a handful of 2- and 4-top tables and eight spots at the sushi bar, so it gets crowded quickly, as we saw. We started with an order of shumai that came with an unusually thick teriyaki dipping sauce. As the order had a odd-number of pieces, we both eyed  the last one for a few minutes before deciding who would get it. (Solution in future: two orders.) For dinner, my companion had the Sushi A combo with one substitution ($1 extra), and I had a shrimp maki and six pieces of a la carte nigiri (2 each of striped bass, albacore, and shrimp). The fish was fresh, the rolls were cohesive and tasty, the seaweed was crisp...in all, we had a decent meal for not a lot of money.

This place is pretty standard sushi fare. I'm a vegetarian, and their selection is not anything above average. Their house salad has lettuce that is practically white, and the dressing isn't very flavorful. The standard cucumber and avocado roll is good, as is their edamame. I wish they had more of a vegetable roll with more ingredients. Ponzu sushi up the street has a great veggie roll. I do like that Greentea has free byob. The servers are also nice and attentive.

Can you say "crunchrolls?" This place has great sushi at affordable prices. Crunch roll, although not on the menu, is the best roll in town if u like tempura. Also the spicy tuna is the best i've had.

Their food is really good for a very reasonalble price. The ingredients are fresh and they use real crab for the California rolls. Everything they make is so delicious from miso soup, sushi, dumplings  to salads. Their menu is not vast, they make rolls, sashimi, salads, and some appetizers. No Tonkatsu or udons but I love the simplicity. The best Japanese I have found in Chicago.

Greentea is my new go-to sushi place. Why? The sushi is delicious and it is SO CHEAP! I love the Alaska roll (salmon and avocado with roe). There are always huge pieces of fish in the roll. Sometimes cheap sushi places load up on the rice, but Greentea does not skimp on the fish or flavor. I usually get takeout because I live a block away and the restaurant is tiny. There's maybe room for 12 people in the restaurant, so be prepared to wait a little bit. I promise the sushi's worth it, though.

If you stop by this sushi bar there is no question to whether you should get the spicy tuna roll or something else on the menu. I'm sure everything else is amazing but when great chefs perfect a particular dish like the guys at greentea have done with the spicy tuna roll then you have to order it.  How is it so cheap and so good?? The place is pretty small and the parking can be bad so I usually go the pickup order route. Frieking love it.

To be honest, it's my best sushi experience in the city.  Part of that has to do with the friends I dine with and the BYOB atmosphere, but even without all that it is the best for value, price and atmosphere.  A super small shop I get the feeling it make most of it's money from takeout.  The chef's are constantly filling clear to go containers during your meal, but as a dine in customer I have never felt that service was slow even after the second or third order.  Highlights are the fried salmon roll and the soft shell crab.  There is definitely tons of delicious sushi in the city and I recommend going out to see other restaurant's specialty rolls, but no matter how delicious or creative I always find myself coming back to Greentea.

The quality and price of the sushi here are insane. The freshest sushi and ingredients for prices that really are a steal.  A very small restaurant, with usually a long wait, that will have you unequivocally hooked with one bite.  Oh yeah, it's also BYOB, which makes everything in this world that much better.
one of my favorite "to go" Sushi spots, also a great classic california roll.

Ordered takeout from Greentea Sushi tonight. It was terrible. Mayo all over everything. The California roll did not even seem to be real crab, more like a crab salad with avocado in a roll. The rest was tasteless. The good reviews are surprising because we will definitely not be going back.

I haven't been to Greentea for over a year, but I definitely have not forgotten about this great sushi spot.   I'm really impressed with the quality of their sushi and the price they offer it at.  I feel like I can leave feeling happy, satisfied and with money still in my pockets.  It's pretty small, but I haven't had too hard of a time getting a table.   Great place for a casual date or catching up with a friend.  It's unpretentious, but not a whole in the wall either, so it strikes a nice balance for those who don't want anything fancy, but are a little sketched out by whole in the wall restaurants.
Delicious! I moved away from Lincoln Park, but still order from Green Tea. It is worth the extra $5 delivery charge. YUM!

greentea continues to impress me, time and time again. situation: takeout on a sunday night. what we ordered: 6 maki rolls -- spicy salmon, spicy hamachi, oshinko, chicago spicy crazy, boston, and ebikyo. how much we paid: 12 dollars each how we ended up:  happy and well-fed with some mighty fine fish seriously, i don't know of any other sushi place in chicago with prices like this and such consistent great quality.  forget the other places on clark street -- this one is the clear winner.
Hands down the best sushi thats cheap and awesome! Must have dishes: - volcano -Crunchy Roll
Great prices and good quality sushi.  Very fresh.  It's a little cramped, but for the price I don't mind.  I'll definitely be back.

Great quality sushi at an affordable price.  It's BYOB (as I'm sure you've read) and there's a nearby liquor store with a decent wine selection. The place is really small so if you have a party of 4, you might be hanging out at the sushi bar for a short wait before being seated; but definitely worth the wait. Their roles are innovative and they have metal puzzles by the register.

Me likey Greentea sushi. And here is why: 1. Its fresh and delicious 2. BYOB 3. Affordable 4. Wide variety of choices, including delicious fried tofu 5. Although the place is small, there is never much of a wait at all. And thats all you really need to know.  They also do a lot of carry out orders. I will normally put my order in and go tanning next door, as soon as you're done, your food will be ready!

I've been here a few times and I'm never disappointed.  The sushi/maki rolls are inventive and delicious. It is small so plan on a wait especially if you go Thurs - Sat.  It's not like Toro's wait which I appreciated. However, they do have bar seating which works well if you don't want to wait for a table or if you are on a date.. if you have more than 2 people....not so much. BYO as well.

I've seen Green Tea for years, but we'd usually head to Sushi Para Too a few doors up, or House of Sushi and Noodles for typical sushi buffet piggery.  My neighbors raved about Green Tea long ago, but warned that it's pretty hard to get seated as they only have about 3-4 tables in addition to a sushi bar.  I took a couple of friends there over the weekend and felt like firing the buffet places after taking the first bite of my very fresh, almost buttery avocado and spinach rolls.  And the New York roll is pure ambrosia. The sushi rice at other places taste like starchy pellets compared to the moist, flavorful rice used at Green Tea. And no pun, the green tea here is wonderful, too.  There's no buffet option here that I know of, but I look forward to diving more deeply into their menu to try more complex rolls next time!

Love, love, love this place! I come here every time I go to the zoo. The staff are ultra sweet and friendly, and the food is divine. The place is tiny and there's sometimes a bit of a wait, but it's so worth it. Get a Volcano, it's especially so yum!

i tend to get pretty stingy on my stars when writing sushi reviews, but greentea earns four full ones from me, & for good reason. thanks to my boyfriend's recent move to the clark/fullerton area, we've been on a mission to try all of the sushi spots within a five block radius (believe me, there are a lot.) i'm ashamed to say, greentea was the last one on our list. if we had only knew how great this place is, we would have visited a lot sooner. let me lay it all out for you: the flavors are simple & fresh. sushi lovers, rejoice. if you are looking for high quality sushi with fresh fish & ingredients, this is the place for you. if you are someone who prefers specialty rolls & crazy non-traditional sushi combinations - this is not the place for you. greentea's menu is very basic, but they are extremely good at what they do. greentea sushi chefs take great care in making their sushi. no joke, they make spicy rolls TO ORDER. really - your spicy tuna/salmon/hamachi etc. doesn't get pulled out of a vat of pre-made stuff they prepared last night. they mix each spicy roll by hand. and that is crazy (good!) another note about greentea's version of "spicy." greentea uses green onions/scallions along with a house-made sauce to create the spicy mix. it's not a "hot" spicy, but rather spice spicy, which may be disappointing to some of you who prefer a little kick with your sushi.  do you hate deep-fried rolls because the fish on the inside arrives warm or half cooked? at greentea, tempura fried rolls are fried first, then filled after the outside of the roll has cooled. that is some serious dedication to the craft right there. we all know that good sushi sometimes comes at a cost, but not at greentea. all of the "basic" rolls are under $5. the most expensive roll i saw on the menu was $12, with most maki under $10. we ordered edamame, two nigri pieces & four rolls and walked out with a bill under $50 (including tax & tip.) i can't think of a better sushi value than that (don't even think about mentioning that crappy AYCE place down the street.) and the cherry on top? it's a BYOB with no corkage fee. they only obvious downside to greentea is that it is pretty small. but, from our visit, it looks like they have quite a bit of to-go orders come through the restaurant, so that's always an option. very much looking forward to munching on some greentea sushi again!

Before last night, I've only been here once before a little while ago and it was a fast dinner so I felt I didn't really get a chance to experience enough to give an opinion, let alone a whole review.  After dinner last night with a friend, I def like it more than the first time. I prefer regular sushi restaurants over buffets, because at buffets they pack more rice than the actual food inside. And, everything isn't as fresh. That is why they can charge so less. You get what you paid for.  Aside from the fresh rolls at Green Tea, the price is really reasonable, so that is why it's comparable to alot of buffets when it comes to casual and less expensive sushi restaurants.  Another plus is that it's BYOB and no corkage fee.  Only negative is that the place is super tiny and cozy. But that doesn't seem to stop people from going, it's always busy whenever I pass by and my friend and I waited for over half an hour last night. I will def be coming back!

Hidden Gem....that's not so hidden any more. This sushi spot in Lincoln Park is one of the best in the area.
