We lived about 3 blocks from Greentea and frequented it almost once a week.  The one thing that always remained constant was the great service and fresh fish that Greentea served. The one thing that I must note, getting a seat is sometimes very difficult. There are about 8 tables and a total of about 25 seats in this restaurant. Takeout is always a great option for those who don't have the patience to wait around for a table.
Great, creative sushi with really good flavor.  Fresh.  Try the Lobster Maki.  Friendly service.  Decent ambiance in a small Soave. Good prices

This is the place to be for FRESH sushi, unique rolls and BYOB! My friends and I visit this place quite frequently and we usually get plateful of sashimi, tons of rolls and end up to be around $25-$30 each! With BYOB in combination, this place is a good casual dining scene. The place is a tad bit small so try to not come during peak hours. Also, they do very good take out so you can call ahead and order as well. Must have dishes: - volcano - baked scallop with mayo and shrimp roe. - white tuna roll which is the special roll - salmon belly sashimi! (not on menu, but can request!) - sweet shrimp - my suggestion is to get it as sushi as he garnishes them in the most wonderful way and for those who dare, get the deep fried shrimp head (optional) as well! Don't be fooled about the fact that they operate by Thai people. The chef is trained by a japanese and he has a lot of pride in it! Plus he's fun.

This is our place for sushi!! We tried a few others, but we keep going back here because their quality-price ratio is the best! It's very small and you can't make reservations.. so we often end up eating at the counter, but I quite enjoy watching the chefs preparing the sushi with their special art. The food is very good and fresh, I love the dragon roll, rainbow roll and the caterpillar, but everything is really tasty. Sure, the waitresses aren't champions of social skills, but I really don't care about that. Prices are super good so you can actually indulge yourself in that extra roll that you always want.. and it's BYOB too! really, Green Tea is a gem!
I honestly don't think my husband has ever been able to drive by the place without stopping to get something.  Very fresh fish.

I didn't really like this place. We ordered delivery and I was definitely underwhelmed.  Because of the low prices we ordered a TON of rolls and not one would I have wanted to order again - not even the Chicago Spicy which sounded amazing. The tuna avocado salad was NOT good - the flavors did not taste good and it was not a salad.  It was a mush of tuna with avocado on top.  I couldn't even eat it (coming from someone who can pretty much eat anything). The rolls were virtually flavorless - super bland and felt like mostly rice.  The spicy tuna was most definitely not spicy and the hamachi was the only roll that we finished.  The prices are really good, but I would definitely rather pay more to actually enjoy the sushi.  I don't think we will order from here again.
The sushi is fantastic, I don't think I've ever had fresher tasting sushi. Prices are reasonable too. The waitress was ok, but the food was ready quickly and did not disappoint

I've been to almost every sushi place in Lincoln Park and I am very happy that I finally found this place! I still think Sushi Toro and Wakamono are the best places in the neighborhood, but this is much more affordable and convenient.  I've only been a weekday, but I've never had to wait for a table and it's BYOB which is great. The NY roll is my favorite.  The crunchy roll and spicy California roll are also great.  If you haven't tried it, I highly recommend it.

If you're craving sushi and want the best bang for your buck, this place is it! Yes, it's extremely small, but somehow, they make it work! The prices are very cheap compared to other place and quality is above average. A great place for a cozy date. Bring a bottle of white wine or mascato and you're good to go! I'll definitely be back. Wish I lived in Lincoln Park!

Green Tea is reasonably priced and has a great variety of sushi rolls that are absolutely amazing. I have been eating at this restaurant since High School and still keep coming back for more. I suggest ordering it to-go because its small and its BYOB. Overall its amazing.

This is my standard sushi restaurant. It's reasonably priced, fresh, and well presented. We went with a party of 7 and fit nicely at the bar - no small feat in such a small restaurant! Be prepared to wait if you're with a large party. The bus boy was excellent with heating up your sake quickly, and the waitress was fantastic. I will continue to frequent this spot.

Once in a blue moon I like dressing up and paying for overpriced sushi while sipping on $13 martini's.  However, those nights become expensive and obnoxious.  Greentea is my little secret sushi oasis that I frequent when I just want some damn good fish.  This is by FAR by fave low key sushi spot.  It's casual and simple.  And the food certainly hits the spot.  Name another place in LP where you can feed three hungry girls for under $35 while successfully getting them tipsy (loving the byob)?? And might I add, dessert is just up the street at Molly's.  Another reason why I love Greentea. Wait, did I just concoct the perfect date night in LP?.....You're welcome :)

Green Tea is a reasonably priced and serves pretty good sushi. They serve the spiciest wasabi I ever tasted. It's a really small restaurant and usually not too crowded. The Chicago Roll is one of the best rolls on the menu as far as I remember. Give it a try.

Small, quaint place with fabulous sushi rolls. The staff are friendly and extremely knowledgable in their fish selection and they have the BEST SPICY TUNA I HAVE EVER HAD. Stranded on a desert island, that would be one of the 3 things I choose to take with me, yes its that good. Its BYO and once you are seated, they are quick to get your order and bring it to you. A pleasant suprise all around!
FRESH sushi at a reasonable price! This is the kind of quality you get from a $$$ place in Chicago minus the high price and good service.

Solid.  And reasonably priced.   Sushi seems fresh, and it is artfully presented.  It may not be the best sushi I've ever had, but for the price, it's a pretty good deal.  Cups of decent tea are only $1 and refills are frequent....I do wish that a place called "greentea" would actually have some more japanese teas for you to select, or maybe a tea menu.... Overall, we (2 people) got the crispy roll (REALLY crispy), spicy tuna roll, tuna roll, boston roll, two green teas, AND edamame for only $32 (including tip).  Yeah you read that right yelp community-you can stuff your hipster faces with sushi for only around $16 a person.... Ambiance is relaxed-it's not going for the trendy, I want to yell at you over some bad techno kind of crowd, which was actually a relief in the current chicago sushi scene. I'm going to go back for lunch, where they have bento boxes around $7-9. Will be back for dinner as well.

After much prompting via the Yelp 'Welcome' page, I decided to try Green Tea sushi again. By "try" I mean gorge viciously to the point where the waitstaff are shooting eye daggers at me; though they are too afraid to speak to me, what with bits of tako and toro hanging from my mouth.   My orbicularis oris is tensed with amusement at these malevolent looks from the staff. I get out of my chair, approach this pleasant looking woman, ask her how I should ingest the sushi, and the proceed to walk slowly back to my table-encouraging her to follow me. She daintily picks up one piece of tai, it being a white fish, and places it gently in my gullet.  No soy sauce or extra wasabi (there already is a bit of wasabi on it thanks to the chef).  After working through the white fish she then moves onto the darker pieces-red snapper, tuna, salmon, etc. After a while she begins to give me that don't-you-want-to-take-some-of-this-sushi-home-because-you-can't-possibly-be-such-a-fat-ass-as-to-eat-all-of-this... I was going to make her feed me all of the sushi.  The process began with her appearing to be delighted in enlightening an ignorant American, then progressed to her having arm cramps and bite marks from not feeding me fast enough, then finally ended with her running away from the table in tears of confusion as Stockholm Syndrome developed between the two of us. Well, I ended taking some sushi home.  Should you go to this sushi restaurant when there are tons of others littering the neighborhood?  Well, I'll let you decide for yourself.   However, if you don't go, I'll track you down via your IP address...

This was a very pleasant surprise! I was just walking down Clark on my way to another sushi restaurant and decided to go here instead, and I'm glad I did. The sushi is all very reasonably priced and tastes very good. The green tea was great too, and our waitress re-filled it often. Like the other reviews indicate, the place is pretty small, so don't come here with a huge group at busy times or you may be stuck waiting for a table for a while.

The best non-froufrou sushi in the city!  I have been going to Green Tea for at least six years now.  Every time I go the sushi is fresh.  It is always busy around dinner time.  It is a very small place that seats about 20.  I have learned that I prefer to sit toward the front.  The back area get a bit steamy from the oven. All the rolls are good.  I usually get a sushi or sashimi set and mix a a roll with it.  The spicy tuna, crunchy and rainbow are my staples.   There is one waitress.  She is very nice and helpful, but isnt around all the time.  Sometimes you have to wave her down.  Green Tea is a great place to go have a great relaxing dinner and bring your own Vino or Cerveza.   See you tomorrow!

Pretty decent sushi.  Pretty horrible service.  Good takeout. The place is across the street from me so I might go back.  And service can be luck of the draw.  But we honestly did not get any service unless we asked for it.  We asked for a table, we asked to place our order, we asked for water, we asked for the check (and got a roll of the eyes for doing so).  Could be a bad experience and I am willing to try it again.  But for now . . . 3 stars.

Wow, this place is good! We had seven different rolls, and I really liked their crunchy Salmon Roll, and the fresh spicy scallop roll. I found their prices to be fair, and the food to be great! It's a BYOB, and their dining area is very small, so you need to pick a good time to come and grab a table. We had a 15 minute waite on a Tuesday evening, so that wasn't too bad.

I love this place!  I lived down the street for two years and it took me probably 6 months to go and when I finally did I was mad at myself for waiting so long.  It's a small cozy place with great food and average service for a very reasonable price.  The only thing is the waitresses are a little annoying but tolerable.

Hands down my fav sushi joint in the city! Thing with Chicago sushi-eaters (as opposed to west coast) is that everyone in Chicago loves maki, probably because super fresh nigiri/sashimi is hard to come by.  And seems people love creativity. I on the other hand am more a west coast sushi eater -- love love fresh fish.  Leave cream cheese to bagels.   That being said, green tea has fresh sashimi and the value is the best in town!  The traditional maki are top notch.  They use fresh snow crab for their california rolls, they have quail eggs, 5 types of roe and the uni is always fresh.   They even throw in some creative maki (crunchy roll, chicago, crazy spicy) are all awesome because their fish is just so fresh!   Cant say it's the freshest in the city, because that would be Katsu, but I would spend 3x the cost for that freshness.   What I love - Sushi C combination:  just a combination of heaven! for 18 bucks!!  love the uni, love the roe! - Salmon don:  the quality of their sushi rice is unbeatable, topped with 5 slices of delicate, delicious salmon, accompanied by home made japanese pickles.  presented beautifully.  amazing. Service;  the place is very small, a lot of their business is via take out orders, so there usually a wait for a table if you come on friday/sat nights.  after seated, maybe have to wait a bit, but if you come during the week, this shouldn't be much of an issue. can't say more great things about the food. oh and don't forget BYOB.

Great little sushi place at a great price.  Small, BYOB and sometimes takes a little too long to be served after placing your order, but all tolerable because the quality of the good. I thought this was a hidden gem of lincoln park, but 120 some reviews tell me otherwise.  Great for take-out.

ok we tried this place after hearing so many good things in yelp. Excellent, Fantastic, Tasty, Cheap (for sushi anyways) thats how i would describe this place.  the interior is small with limited seating, but it does add to the charm.  it can take some time to get your food, thats cause they are so busy with takeout.   Yelp you also get 5 stars for recommending this place.

I tried Greentea based on Yelp reviews and was SO not disappointed.   We had so many rolls I rolled out of there.  And our total was $50 -- I ate for twice that at Coast recently. The spicy tuna roll is the best around.  We loved a crawfish maki -- can't remember the name of it.  The unagi and caterpillar were great.  Very fresh, lots of flavor!  WILL DEFINITELY GO BACK!  Great sushi for the money.

Greentea... Your SLIPPING!  I have been to Greentea a handful of times, they are literally across the street from where I live and I love Sushi! The first time I had their sushi I ordered out and it was great! Super fresh, great presentation, and a great price.  Then I dined in with a friend and it too held up to the five star rating.  But the last two time I have been there they have been terrible!  A friend and I went to the restaurant to eat in.  We waited maybe 15 min for a table which was fine but the annoying thing was that we waited 45 mins after we placed our order!! It was only a few rolls and a few pieces!  The most annoying thing, there was another group that came in about 10 mins after us, were seated and had a bunch of food on their table in about 5 mins!!!  They where finished by the time we got our food?!?! WHAT was THAT! Annoyed but full. I decided that I would try them again, this time I would take away, I mean hell they have great food!  So I picked up my food and noticed that all the sushi was just kinda thrown in there, no real presentation, def. not like it was the first time I ordered out!! Then I got home and there was no ginger in the box, no wasabi, and the fish was just ok!  So this review is for Greentea mostly!! You guys need to keep your quality control, people expect something and when they don't consistently get it they will leave!  I hope you guys will change and do this because your so close to where I live and I love supporting the small guys!  Hope you Do, I will be back but it will probably be the breaking moment if its like the last two time!

One day, we wanted sushi.  So we typed in "best sushi" into yelp, and this popped up.  And boy, what a great example of how wonderful yelp is.  The restaurant is a perfectly little (and when we say little...we mean little) shop with 6 tables at most and a few seats at the counter with the perfect view of their genius sushi chefs doing their magic.  The sushi is just as you'd expect from a small sushi shop (perhaps in Japan?).  It's fresh, expertly made (i.e. does not fall apart), and delicious.  Not only that, everything is reasonably priced.  We were able to stuff ourselves with their specialty rolls and leave with more money left than if we had gone to a place like Sushi Para II.   Their saving grace, however, is also their downfall.  As it is so small, most people get take-out.  This can slow down the very critical order-to-mouth time, since nearly 3 of every 4 sushi rolls the chef makes leaves the restaurant.  If you come on a Friday/Saturday night, you could also expect a long wait...possibly out on the street.  So come early and come hungry, and you'll soon forget about how long you waited.
Love this place! BYOB, and some of the freshest sushi in the city. Great quality and good prices.

My absolute favorite sushi place in the city! The prices for the quality cannot be beat. My only wish is that the place was bigger. I like to eat at a busy restaurant, but not one that I can barely be comfortable in.

Unfortunately, we never got past the girl who answered the phone.  She answered the phone, didn't seem interested in our business, and said the delivery would take over an hour.  When I said that would still be OK, she asked us to hold on.  Then she set the phone down and I listened and waited for close to 15 minutes as she cashed out patrons in the restaurant and completely forgot about me.  When I hung up and tried to call back, the line was busy.  There are so many great sushi places in Lakeview, you can do better than this type of service.

Not even a huge sushi fan, but Greentea really showed me what I was missing in sushi. The absolute BEST sushi I ever had. The prices are unbeatable and the service is speedy as well as friendly. Offering a variety of sushi, I cannot wait to check this quaint little spot again.

Green Tea was great! Me and ma friend had Volcano there as appetizer. It's scallop finely baked with spicy mayo. Very impressive! So overall was great with Green Tea. I was amazed that even though the chefs are not Japanese, they do make real Sushi and not just fool people around. Thanks for the great work!
Great for pickup and delivery, okay for Dine-in but a tad small. Excellent sushi for the price.  Their Motto: Thank you, see you tomorrow...

The food is exceptional. It great from top to bottom.  The price, amazing. But ...and it's a big but....I don't know how you can look past the service.  From start to finish, it's like pulling teeth. If you call for pick-up, you'll be met with a 10 minute "hold please", a busy signal, or the telephone companies long delayed silence, and then buzzing. (that last one confuses me everytime) My attempt at sidestepping the poor service, by ordering it for takeout, and showing up at the stated time (an hour later), failed miserably. When I showed up, there was at least 10 others people standing in the 4x4 waiting area, near the door. I'm not sure you can call it a waiting area though, seeing that you are standing on top of the 3 tables near the window, and shoulder to shoulder with the people at 6 seats at the bar. As I waited, for the first 30 minutes, I actually expected the food to be made at any time. As the next 30 minutes passed, I began to contemplate on walking out. I waited for another 30 minutes, and finally, I got a 'head nod" that I was coming up soon. The woman at the cash register, throughout the whole process, fumbled her food-tickets, looked panicked, and had an overall difficult time filling orders. I'm not sure where the ordering equipment came from, but I believe it dates back to the Carter Administration. With their popularity, there is no reason they haven't upgraded the equipment, and I can't see how they can keep customers content when one has to wait 2 and a half hours for their food. And I can't understand why no-one ever took the time to say..."Hey, we are behind, I'm sorry, we'll be with you as quickly as possible".  In a fast paced city, I think people deserve a bit more punctuality. I guess these owners hit the jackpot with their prime location, because NOTHING, is worth this type of wait. Oh, I forgot to mention, to the woman who lent me the 5 quarters to fill up my parking machine, thank you very much! You're a doll. My suggestion, take something to keep yourself occupied, if you go there!

Pretty good. A little slow service, but they were busy. I'd go again if I first went to the other restaurants in the area. Would be 4 stars if it was easier to eat healthy. I'd also have enjoyed it better if I were better at ordering sushi. Read  eugeneciurana.com/musing…  next time if you're not already a pro. "*People who know how to eat sushi don't order California rolls. They're for wimps who can't handle raw fish. Rule of thumb: if it has mayonnaise or tomatoes, or if it's cooked and lacks an exotic name like ankimo, it's probably not real sushi."

The food here is good, but I'm giving the place ONE star because of a truly horrifying experience I had here this evening. I loved this place but I will never return. First of all, I travel all the way from the South Side to go to this restaurant. That's a trek. But like I said, the food is great despite it's truly lousy atmosphere and service and if I'm in the mood for sushi and want to get out of Hyde Park, I'll go to Green Tea. Tonight I ordered an avocado roll, a "crunch" roll, and 2 pieces of salmon nigiri. The first course came and it was fine, as did the second. But the nigiri took at least 30 minutes to come after I ordered it, and the restaurant, which holds 25 people was only at half capacity, if that. The first piece of nigiri was very good. The second still had a bit of that irridescent connective tissue attached to it, so I couldn't bite it. And I tried it even holding in my hand. Now, I probably could have sawed through with my incisors if I wanted to, but that's unappetizing if not utterly gross. I like my fish disembodied, thank you. That hits a little too close to home.  Anyway, the waitress is very slow - nice, but UNBELIEVABLY slow - and I had already waited 30 minutes for two pieces of nigiri (what was the chef doing, forging the knife and going to Alaska to catch the salmon just for me?!) so I brought the intact piece with BITE MARKS - flipped over so he could see the offending tissue that was preventing me from tearing the fish - to the sushi bar (there was only one guy eating at it, all the way to the end), and VERY politely and VERY quietly, practically in a whisper, asked the chef in charge (who is also the owner, come to find out!), for another piece because I couldn't bite it. I returned to my seat. I work at a restaurant so I completely understand that things aren't always perfect. Next thing I know, I hear him yelling for me to come back, saying he'd "never heard of such a thing in his life" and he "gave me the best part of the fish". Now, it may have been prime meat (it was, I could tell) but it still had that tendon-type stuff attached to it so I couldn't enjoy it. So he tells me that I'm wrong. That I should come and pick out the part of the fish that I want. I tell him that whatever part is fine as long as he doesn't cut it so close to the skin that that happens again. He, again, tells me I am wrong, and sarcastically cuts me a super-thin piece. I tell him that I want to leave and just will take the check instead. So he yells at me - YELLS at me like a father yells at his KID - in front of the whole restaurant. Then he MAKES me take the nigiri he cut despite the fact that I just asked for the check in an effort to end the insanity, and he doesn't even hand it to me - I had to reach over and get the dish myself. This sounds fake, I know. But I'm dead serious here. All of the customers were staring at him like he was nuts because he was yelling at a young, female, quiet customer for something that he had done. I kept saying, "can we stop arguing please?", and he yelled "NO!" and kept telling me that I was wrong and rude for asking for a new cut. All this over a $1.75 piece of nigiri. Sound a little irrational to you? Oh, and I still got charged for the piece, not that that should surprise you at all given the owner's response to my request for a new piece of nigiri. So to recap: the owner of Green Tea cut the fish wrong. I politely asked for a new piece that I could chew, and he yelled at me and told me I was wrong, then cut me a tiny piece and forced me to reach over and retrieve it to take back to my table, despite the fact that I had told him I wanted the check instead. It was like a scene from a movie. Notably, as a waitress, I still left my server (who was pretty bad, never once checked on me), a 20% tip, because I didn't want to take out my disappointment with the owner on her. Unless you think that patronizing a mean guy who would actually humiliate a customer loudly in front of the restaurant for HIS mistake is worth it for some good sushi, I wouldn't recommend coming here. There are dozens of other sushi places within a mile-radius of Green Tea, and they may only be 90% as good, but chances are, the owners of these other places won't verbally abuse you if you have a concern.
Probably one of the best local spots for fresh sushi. Chicago spicy and Caterpillar rolls are to die for. There is always a line at this tiny location but it is more than worth the wait.

I actually passed this place up on my way to another, overcrowded sushi bar. When it was apparent that the hostess could not care less about the patrons waiting to be seated, we left, and decided to give this place a chance when we were driving around looking for another place to eat. The nigiri was fresh and delightful. I wasn't impressed with some of the unevenly made maki rolls, but in general, the quality of the fish was great and made for an excellent dinner. The restaurant is tiny, with barely any elbow room. This place is definitely worth a repeat, if you don't mind the lack of privacy in such a small space.

I somehow always get the same bar seat every time I come here.  They must have some sort of telepathic powers and kick people out of it when they know I'm coming.  I tried to throw them off one day, but lo and behold, guess where I ended up. Random tangent: They have a cool sushi clock. The sushi is fresh and delicious.  The rolls are flawlessly constructed.  I usually order off the menu, since I'm moody when it comes to my sushi, but one day I'll try omakase.  Back here time and time again. If you walk in and see somebody that looks like me in the 5th stool from the wall, it's probably me.  I do autographs.
This place is really great and the sushi is good and not overpriced! The only downside is that its so small! I went here with two other people (my mom and a friend) and even then, it felt cramped.

A great hole-in-the-wall sushi place in LP. Great fish, great portions, great prices. Try the salmon skin roll, only 4.25 and it's HUGE. Loaded with delicious fried salmon skin, and they even stack some slices on the side of the plate. Also, I recommend sitting in view of the amazing skills of their sushi chefs, who can do mesmerizing things with knives and cucumbers...

Love this place. I have eaten at many sushi places but still like Green tea the best in terms of value. The fish is always fresh here. The only problem here is that the restaurant is so tiny. It might take a while to get table on a busy night. I'd rather go early or go on weekdays.

When I first moved into my apartment 2 years ago, it didn't take me long to fall in love with Greentea Sushi. WIthin the first month at our new place we tried Greentea one Saturday around 5:30 p.m. Little did I know then that we were lucky to get a table, even as early as 5:30.  Greentea has incredible fresh fish, amazing prices, and it's BYOB. We left stuffed and only spent about $35.00! Since my first time dining in, I haven't been back to actually dine in, but I get carry-out religiously.  Living so close, I can call in my order, have it ready within 25 minutes and not have to hassle with the crowds (it gets INCREDIBLY crowded).  Hands down my favorite sushi place. If you like silly frilly cream cheese rolls, beware. This place isn't for you and your idea of sushi =)

oh green tea, how i miss thee!  Hands-down my favorite Chicago sushi spot. Every time I go to eat sushi, whether in santa cruz/san fran when I'm in school or NYC when I visit my girlfriends, EVERY TIME I eat sushi, I compare it to this place.  I compare the quality of the fish, the price, the courtesy of the staff.   I have NEVER found a place that can outdo the food at green tea at the same price point.  Places like Ra and Tsunami by my old pad are pricier and not even as good.  To eat better fresher sushi I have to drop more than I spend on groceries a week.  Why do that when you can eat such great food at green tea?  Also, they have a great appetizer that they call Vocano, a baked spicy scallop dish.  Totally delicious, I crave it like a pregnant woman, and it is very difficult to find elsewhere.  Now that I'm stuck in school in cali I try to make it myself - no bueno - they must have some secret. The chefs are also super nice.  Even that guy at the end who looks like he's scowling, when you get up to leave will join the others and beam 'see you tomorrow!!'  It's not some avant-garde, experimentalist roll business, but if sushi is your comfort food, this is your new neighborhood joint.

Greentea has some pretty excellent sushi.  I mean really good stuff; the spicy hamachi roll was killer, the caterpillar roll was perfectly constructed with fresh unagi and avocado (and didn't fall apart), and the spicy tuna roll was described as "the best I've ever had" by my lady friend.  The prices are fantastic.  Somehow the two of us managed to order 5 (?!) rolls and we still walked out of there with a check under $40. The place is quite small.  If you sit at one of the elevated tables, you will have a fantastic view of the sushi chefs working their magic.  However, you will also feel the overpowering heat from the kitchen and the tempura fryer.  Next time I'd sit at the bar.  Which brings me to my only complaint; the service.  We ordered in two waves, and each of them took at least 30 minutes from order to receiving our food.  I was tempted to 3-star this place just based on my frustration of watching people who had come in after us get their food significantly before us. Still though; the value is fantastic.

I challenge another Japanese restaurant in the city to place me in an equivalent food coma for the same price. I CHALLENGE YOU!!!! Classic menu and rolls with fresh fish - all for a good deal!! We ordered 5 rolls, 1 soup, 1 gyoza, green teas and ice creams - all for $44!! I was blown away!!! I've had more creative rolls and fancier presentations at other restaurants in the city (Mirai, Sushi Samba, Ra, etc) but paid about 3x the price. The food was solid - nothing to complain about, fast service, easy parking, and I left feeling content and completely STUFFED. :) Foood Commmaaaa. Next time I feel the need to gorge myself without breaking the bank - I'm totally gonna hit up Greentea again.

The sushi was ok. I wasn't super impressed and there wasn't anything original here that you couldn't get elsewhere. I will say that the prices are reasonable and you can get the food to go. My problem is with the service.  I've tried to eat at the physical location twice. Both times we waiting 20 minutes longer than the quoted time (which I had to ask about because the woman just took our name and gave us no estimate).  After waiting 20 minutes longer I wasn't seated but rather went up to ask what was happening and was told it would be another half an hour.  When I was clearly upset by this the second time the server offered to seat us within 10 minutes ahead of other people.  After that I left just like the first time.  The staff seems to care less about the customers since they have so many anyway.  I would rather give my business and money to someone who appreciates it.

the first time we came, my bf and I trying to find Cousins...should've walked in the other direction!  But we stumbled across greentea, saw that it was BYOB and got very excited!  Their baby octopus salad is wonderful and they don't skimp on the octopus.  Their gyoza tastes fresh and home and home made.  All the rolls I've had are delicious and you can tell people love this place because of ALL the take out orders they get.   The restaurant is tiny and you might have to wait for a seat.  But for the price and byobness, it's DEFINITELY worth the wait!

Debating if I should lower it to one star because of the staff. My first impression of this place is, dirty. The person who took care of us had long wavy hair that wasn't pulled back which is a health code violation. I noticed the sushi chef walking in and out, and kept wondering if his hands were clean.  The sushi is cheap, I will give you that. I know it's a chill place, but the service was just horrible. The server was serving food to us while she was on the phone? The fish was mediocre, the rolls were nothing special. We also ordered this volcano appetizer which is baked scallops with spicy mayo sauce, they drenched it with terriyaki sauce, which wasn't appetizing at all. Pros: Good prices, byob Cons: Dirty, bad service, nothing special Will not come back.

Mmmm!!! If you are looking for a great deal on good sushi - this is your place. It's small, so you might have to wait for a place to sit, but the people who work there are nice and they like to say "See you tomorrow!" when you leave. The sushi chefs are really friendly and fun to watch. So about the sushi - I like simple rolls, ones with only about 3 ingredients, so I'm happy when I can get what I like, feel full, and pay very little. Their ingredients taste fresh too. My friend who I usually go with likes more ingredients and she always says how good her rolls are too. And you really can't get a better price for it - it's amazing how cheap some rolls are (both mine were under $5 each). Granted the ones I get aren't huge in size, but I often can't eat a full 2 rolls from other places, so I like going here cause I can get my 2 favorite rolls and be able to eat all of it. So I highly recommend this place for a low key dinner (and it's BYOB). But be prepared to smell like sushi afterward! There is no avoiding that since it's so small...

Very high quality sushi at a very reasonable price.  I benchmark my sushi places by their spicy tuna roll.  Greentea has a spicy tuna roll to rival any other-- big chunks of delicious tuna in ample portion-- and it costs less than four dollars.  My routine at Greentea is to order far more than I think I can eat, stuff myself, and then laugh when they bring the bill.  It's half what I expect every time!

I am so glad my aunt went here and told me about it because I am now a super huge fan!!  I went to Greentea on a Tuesday night and it was packed! Well, there were only 5 tables and the sushi bar (which can seat 7), but there were people constantly coming in and signing up to wait. On top of this, the entire 1 1/2 hours I was there, the phone was ringing off the hook for carryout orders.  So down to business. My friend and I waited about 20 minutes for a table. Not bad at all. We sat down in the corner by the window and were given wine glasses for our Riesling. Yep! This place is BYOB, which means that on top of enjoying the delicious food that Green Tea serves, you can wash it down with your drink of choice. My friend had a few sushi pieces, including the Uni, which they proclaimed was one of the best they ever had. We shared some rolls as well, which were all very good. I don't eat raw fish, however this was the first time I ever ate a raw spicy scallop maki and it was great! What makes these items so good are their affordable prices. We ordered 5 rolls. Three of them were under $3, and it doesn't go incredibly higher. There are many different rolls to chose from, one of which is a Chicago Roll which, I saw, was in the shape of triangles instead of circles. I have never seen anything like that before; it was very interesting to see.  I have to mention the wasabi because it was Oh-so-good.  VERY fresh and spicy; the way wasabi SHOULD be. I must warn everyone who is a stickler for great service. You might not be happy here. Although it is a small restaurant, there is only one girl working as a hostess, waitress, carryout person and busboy. She can only move so fast, and she does try to move fast. There are 3 sushi chefs and they can only move as fast as they can with all the carryout orders they take. We had to wait about 20-25 for our food. I personally don't care, because you can't go into a place like Greentea and expect 5 star restaurant service. This is not pretentious BS, this is real sushi, so if you want your sushi, test your patience.  Good job Greentea! Can't wait to go back.

I wasn't a huge fan of sushi until one day I was invited for a dinner there. Now I go there on every chance I get. My favorite combination is the simple Tuna Roll, and Cucumber Roll. For 12$ I get 24 ROLLS. What more can you want? Service is fast and reliable. I don't recommend eating inside, because it's a small, cramped space and it gets very crowded in the evening, but ordering carryout is super too!!!

Green tea's sushi is fine, but I saw one sushi chief dropped a piece of fish on the floor then picked it back up and pretend nothing had happened. OMG, I will never go back there again. That tiny little place is always busy and we had to wait 45 mins to get our food, what the heck?! Waitress has NO smile on her face, never asked how was our food. Anyways, there are way too many japanese restuarant sout there with good customer service and good food. Sure enough i will never go back to this place.

I tried to get a picture of the fantastic-looking spread we had, but my sister and I gobbled it up and I barely managed to snap one before our plates were empty. That alone should tell you how great this place is!  We ordered 5 rolls and a cucumber salad for dinner. The rice is really good, tasted fresh, not like it had been sitting around all day. Green Tea doesn't do anything really experimental, so if you're looking for a deep friend roll of octopus brains covered with seaweed foam, try elsewhere. Green Tea has simple rolls, but what they do have is GREAT.  We got 2 avocado rolls, 1 spider roll, 1 tempura shrimp roll, and 1 philly roll. My sister likes the cream cheese --I don't-- but she assured me that it was fantastic. The spider roll was good and the tempura shrimp roll was simple, but good. On the plus side, none of the rolls were swimming in sauce. I wanted to order a crunchy roll, but we were just too full. The rolls are a little bigger than I'm used to, so my sister and I pretty much had to roll home ourselves!  Our bill was almost $25, which I think is the least amount I've spend on sushi for 2 people since moving to Chicago.  Also, It's BYOB and there is no corkage fee, so bring some Sake!! The restaurant itself is tiny, decor is non-existent, save a few waving happy cats on the bar. At first, I was hesitant to try this place, but it was great. I would DEFINITELY make the trek in from Oak Park just for Green Tea's sushi.  And I agree with Eric H., it's totally comfort food sushi. I will definitely go again...and soon! Anyone want to come with? :)

Excellent, fresh, sashimi - ordered a combination of sashimi and sushi for a good price. Wandered here after Toro sushi down the street was full.  Has some unique rolls with different ingredients that are fresh and aren't fried for those willing to try new things. Unfortunately, the miso soup at the beginning was really salty and hard to finish. Still a strong recommendation though.

When I crave sushi, I automatically think of Green Tea. After stumbling upon it on a walk home, my boyfriend and I have been coming back here at least once a month. It's is our standard for delicious, unpretentious sushi. We love that we can get away with spending under $25 per person (including tip) and feel like we got everything we desired.  Also a plus: most rolls aren't deep fried and made with cream cheese, popular options at other places. However, speaking of fried - this is the only place I ever order "fried" sushi, it's the crunchy roll. Unspeakably savory. My other favorites are Tako & Rainbow.  "See you tomorrow" Green Tea!

Green Tea doesn't have unique rolls or a hip decor, but what it does have are maki rolls that taste great and won't break your wallet. What more do you need? The service is friendly and fast, the presentation of the food was nice, and the taste was very good. It's a small place so it can fill up quickly, but the chefs work fast. Strongly recommend for good sushi at a great price.

I live very close to Green Tea and have visited often for both dine in and pickup. My review is somewhat mixed. The food is fairly good and well priced but the atmosphere and service can be lacking.  It is very small and on Friday and Saturday nights dine in can be a long wait. The one waitress handles nearly all the tables plus pick up orders and is really pretty rude both in person and on the phone. However, the gentlemen behind the sushi bar are wonderful! The best thing it has going for it is the BYOB no corking fee policy, its good (but not great ) food and the price is right.

My mother actually recommended me this place, but she's not an avid sushi lover like I am. I should have known better when I decided to listen to her. But whatever, I checked the place out. They're closed on Mondays by the way, like most sushi places in the city. So be warned. They also don't have a happy hour, and I'd deduct 1/4 of a star for that. However, their bargain prices make up for it though. Between my boyfriend and I, we ate our hearts out and only dropped $35 on the bill. That's pretty good for sushi! The rice was a little too cooked and mooshy. I forgot what roll I had but I think it was one of their special ones that was deep fried. It was FANTASTIC! However, when I got home, both my boyfriend and I had an upset stomach, and we were pretty sure it was from their sushi. I probably won't go back there ever again unless I was broke and really desperate for sushi.

The best deal on sushi that I've found in Chicago. The selection of rolls is not as big as some other places, but what they do have is really good and cheap. There are dozens of other sushi places closer to where I live but I usually try and make it out to Greentea, if I can. The place is very small, however, and the wait can be really long, so sometimes it's a good idea to order ahead and carry out.

Came here on a Tuesday night around 5:30, we were the only table for a little while.  When we left there were about 4 tables or so.  The sushi was alright, it wasn't bad...but it was by no means the best I've ever gotten.  The thing that I will say is that it was extremely cheap, the rolls were a little small but for the price, it was great.  My friend and I brought a bottle of wine, had 4 rolls and each had a bowl of soup and it was $30 including tax and tip.  I would come back when I'm in the mood for sushi, but not spending a lot of money.

Went here last night for dinner and I must say that two words describe Green Tea...cheap and good.  Now, when it comes to sushi these adjectives, when put in the same sentence can mean DISASTER.  There is nothing worse than rotten fish, which usually means it's cheap as dirt, but somehow Green Tea can offer sushi that won't break the bank and tastes surprising fresh.  In fact, I was floor by how good the hamachi and super white tuna tasted.  I mean....don't get me wrong, we're not dealing with the over-the-top straight off a fishing boat in the pacific rim, like say Katsu  but for the money (which means about $2 per piece) Green Tea is a solid option.  My only complaint is that this place is way too small.  We only had to wait about 15 min to get seated, but they seriously only have about 20 seats in the entire place.  My advice bring along a couple of beers to drink while you wait by the door and prepare yourself for a sushi feast at 50% off of Coast prices.

Greentea offers good sushi, with very generous amounts of fish, at a decent price.  I enjoyed the tuna, salmon, yellowtail and tamago nigiri, though the uni could have been fresher ('not as fresh as what I had in Hawaii', I commented as my wife rolled her eyes).  I also tried the much talked about Chicago spicy crazy roll, which was pretty good, but not spicy at all. The biggest disappointment, however, was the ridiculously long time it took to get our food.  It was close to an hour from the time we got seated to the time our food started arriving at our table.  For one thing, they only one waiter who has to serve all the tables, but also take carry out orders.  And even though they have 3 sushi chefs, they seemed way too busy filling all those carry out orders (or perhaps they just don't work fast enough).  This does not even include the time to wait in line.  I doubt I will have the patience or time to go there again (or maybe carry out is the way to go).

Yes. BYOB and mighty fresh fish. Another bonus -- an not an insignificant one -- is that when the bill comes you don't feel like you were just sucker-punched. Far better than any other sushi place I've been to in Chicago. Recommended.

Greentea satisfies my two basic needs. 1. My basic need for good food 2. My Chinese need for saving money The sushi here is very fresh and the cuts are thick.  They have a good a la carte selection from sake and tamago to ama ebi and anago.  Their lunch specials are great 10 dollars for 5 pieces of nigiri and a roll and 12 dollars for 7 pieces and a roll and some even cheaper roll deals (the california rolls here are also made with real crabmeat and very good)  Ordering a la carte here is also very affordable as a piece of nigiri averages around 2 dollars. Service and ambiance are completely unremarkable but  that's not what you come here for.  For good sushi at very affordable prices, I haven't found a better place in Illinois.

This is an excellent small sushi bar for casual diners.  I highly recommend this for couples, and would suggest limiting any groups to 4 or less.  The sushi is cheap and the atmosphere is well-suited for neighborhood regulars.   Grab a bottle of wine and enjoy a relaxing dinner that won't break the bank.

Does this sushi place have ambiance - no but do they make amazing sushi? Absolutely! I love the fact that they have BYOB and that although the sushi takes a long time to make as they seem to be true artists, but it's so worth it without questions. I think that it's well priced and although there are not a lot of tables - take out seemed to be very popular (so I would definitely choose this option if you don't feel like going out!)

Went there last night, and while I wish I could give it a 3.5 I bumped it up to 4 stars because its so CHEAP. A sushi A sampler, 4 pieces of sashimi, one roll, one appetizer, and mochi ice cream for $35. Amazing. The sashimi was really good, excellent quality, especially the salmon. The rolls were good too. My only complaint was that the sushi wasn't very cold.  The service was meh. I think there was only one waitress and we had to flag her down a couple of times, but she was generally pretty nice.  Overall, this is great sushi for the price.

Chicago Spicy (something) roll = MY OBSESSION. This roll is AMAZING, you get 10 pieces for the price of 10.95 (or 11.95). I definitely think this is better than your typical dragon roll. I can't wait to go back and order this again !

Amazing sushi.  Not the place to go if you want atmosphere but def. the best Sashimi in the city.  The chefs are great, the price is right, the cuts are amazing, and the service...well the service leaves something to be desired, but hey, can't win em all.  Try the summer roll and the crunchy roll if you're not a Sashimi fan.  Better yet, do both.

LOVE the BYOB!!!  Sushi is HANDS DOWN the best in the city....NO JOKES!  It is SUPER fresh and tastes oh so good!!!!!!!!  The miso soup is also the BEST miso soup in the city!  I would go here every single day.....there is not ONE THING on the menu that is bad.....and I have tried quite bit.....

Greentea is the type of place you will either love or hate.  First off its VERY small......VERY, 5 tables and a sushi bar that seats 7. If you decide to go on a weekend be prepared to wait and to spend your time wondering when people are going to be finished so you can snag their table. This fact may also hamper your dinning experience as you may be uncomfortable knowing those poor people are standing eyeing your table hungrily.  Secondly there is only ONE waitress and ONE bus boy to handle all the tables AND takeout orders. To the waitress' credit, she NEVER gets flustered, rude or agitated with requests. I want to applaud her for working so smoothly by herself.  For some, the two factors mentioned above make this place undesirable. Well for MOI, a broke law student, Greenteas LOW prices AND great vegetable sushi make it ALL worth it!!!!!!!!!!! My meal of tofu appetizer(with GREAT sesame sauce) and two vegetable rolls was only $10 pre tax/tip. You CANNOT beat that with a STICK! Plus, it's in a convenient location and pay box parking means you don't need a gazillion quarters.  I am a fan of Greentea and will definitely be frequenting the establishment for my midweek sushi fixes.

Had a wonderful experience here last weekend.  The place is TINY, so after reading reviews here, we made sure to go early. We were seated right away (at the only table left) and got excellent service. The sushi is to DIE FOR and very affordable. I have been to a few other sushi restaurants in the area, but this is by far the best.  Few tips: 1) sit at the sushi bar...service seemed faster and there is much more elbow room there if you can believe it 2) go early otherwise parking and seating is a nightmare. ENJOY!

i frequent Greentea about once every two weeks and find that their lunch specials are one of the better deals around.  However, after eating there yesterday  I became violently ill with food poisoning, confirmed by a doc.  Now, I'm not saying I am 100% positive it was the sushi, but I had a few snacks as the only other meal that day, making the tuna or salmon the likely culprit. So, as someone knowledgeable about disease transmission, I felt obligated to let them know this happened, just incase they had more of what I had eaten left from yesterday.  Instead of saying thanks for letting us know, or apologizing, I got yelled at by the sous chef who told me it was impossible to have been their fish.  Really? Then he asked me what I wanted anyway, a discount?  I was not looking for a discount, just informing them of something they should know.  It's bothersome to be treated that way when I had good intentions and frequent there regularly.  Very rude.

Ya know Greentea, you're really pissing me off.  Bad service once...I'll let it slide.  Bad service three times...shame on you.  I understand that they're small.  And I understand that there's a lot of takeout orders.  But is seems like they're putting their takeout orders before the people who are actually sitting in their restaurant.  We've literally sat in there for two hours.  By the time the food comes you don't even want it anymore.  We had to ask for wine glasses.  We had to borrow the soy sauce from the table next to us.  We didn't even bother waiting for her to bring the check.  We handed off the rest of our food to the table next to us and went up to the counter to pay.  Both couples on either side of us were also aggravated.  Keep it up Greentea, you're going to lose your business.  It's not like you're the only sushi place in town.

Like an idiot, when I read that this place is BYOB, i thought that you could either bring your own, OR buy it here.  NOPE - bring your own, or you're out of luck!  We came unprepared.  So we ordered, and then i hiked 2 blocks, in the snow in February (and yes, of course it was uphill both ways!) to the nearest liquor store to get a 6 pack. Well worth it!   By the time i returned, our order had been delivered.  I started with the miso, which was a pretty standard miso soup - nothing stand outish about it, but tasted especially grand after walking in the 10 degree weather. The rolls were very fresh, and they had some interesting combinations - one of which came out, and I was in awe - the pieces were triangles, and spotted with little red eggs (masago, but red!).  It had three types of fish, and was delicious.  I had rolls with salmon, yellowtail, and spicy tuna, and everything was great. Atmosphere - very low key, small and extremely casual...don't come here if you're looking for a trendy type place with cool lighting and decor.  Come if you want cheap, good sushi. We decided on dessert (why not!  we were on vacation!).  I had the green tea mochi balls, and my friend had the green tea ice cream - yum! We ate a bit too much though; after dinner, we were too fat and tired to even think about going out - so beware of that :)

saw this place in the RedEye and now I can't stop going. The sushi is fresh and the prices are unbelievably low, this is the type of sushi place that has recession prices all year round. I mean, a tuna roll for less than $3? unheard of. It's super tiny though so if you go at peak times you will wait, so if you think you're craving sushi right about when everyone else is, then just order carryout!!
Amazing.  Best cheap sushi in Chicago.  The Summer Roll is life changing.

I wish I could give 3.5 stars.. But on to the review. Sushi here is good. Fresh and tasty. I took some stars off because the rice was too wet, and the fish wasn't cold enough. Even with these issues, the sushi still tasted excellent. The prices were unbelievably low. The staff was adequate. The place was tiny. I would eat here again.

Sushi you say? Hell yes I'll join you for dinner! And you never have to ask me twice. I will practically rearrange my schedule for a sushi dinner and I'm glad I did for this little gem. The inside is very small. They literally only have 6 tables and then a long sushi bar (I think you can fit 7 or 8 there). So come early is the lesson learned here and be prepared to be amazed at the amazing sushi. The prices are really cheap. Cheap enough to make me skeptical about the quality of the fish. However, I was oh so pleasantly surprised. The fish is melt in your mouth, like butta good! I was so impressed and so were my two dining companions. The place is also BYOB so it's a great cheap spot to eat. If you want to be my friend just ask me to come along with you I'll most certainly oblige!

I love this sushi place. The sushi FRESH and always good. The price is right and they deliver. Too small for a group of 5 or more. The receptionist\server is a bit rude. Never a thank you out of her mouth. I come for the great sushi so I can ignore her rudeness. BYOB is a plus. I have sushi 4 times out of the week and I get my sushi from Green Tea. YUM!
i was mistaken about daikon on the salad... and the best thing here is hands down the bonito.

I've become a semi-regular since re-introducing myself to Greentea. It really hits my sushi spot and doesn't put too much of a dent in my wallet.  I really like this place, my only 2 gripes are as follows:  (1) I think there's too much mayo in the spicy tuna and salmon  (2) Skip the spicy hamachi, for some reason they really seem to skimp on the fish in this roll. It's made inside out and at least 75% of each piece is rice Bottom line: I got 3 rolls for just under $14. Were they the best I've ever had? No, but this place gets a solid 3.5 stars for fresh fish, reasonable prices and consistency. Note to self: Self, next time you call in your order save yourself some cash and disappointment, DO NOT get the spicy hamachi, you always regret it - enough already!

After reading all the great reviews, I was excited to try Green Tea. I was intimidated by the long wait times, so I went the take-out route. The woman who answered the phone was somewhat awkward and rude, but she got the job done. They quoted me at 45 minutes, and it definitely took the whole 45, if not 50.  When I showed up I was surprised to find a cute little restaurant. True, there's only about 5 tables, but it was a nice atmosphere, and I would definitely consider coming for dine-in service at an off peak time.  Pick-up service was very strange. It was a Saturday night, yet one woman was in charge of taking phone orders, being the waitress to the 5 tables, and ringing up pick-up customers. She never really spoke to me, just looked at me and nodded as she darted around the restaurant.  As for the sushi, we got 3 rolls plus edamame for $28, which is definitely impressive. The Chicago Crazy is huge and has lots of very fresh fish, although it's a bit hard to eat. Their spicy tuna was a little too mayo-y for my liking, but it had good flavor. The Caterpillar was good sized and pretty tasty, especially if you're a big avocado fan.  4 stars for the low prices, quality fish and cute restaurant.

Yes, I just want you all to know I turned down dinner at Japonais and Sushi Wabi to come here, and it was so worth it!  It's a tiny place, but the sushi is great here.  If you care about ambiance and need the trendy atmosphere - this might not be the place for you.  It's still a very intimate place, because you will have to crowd together with your group.  It started out with just the 3 of us, and grew to 5.  We brought 2 bottles of wine, and went to town ordering all kinds of menu items.  We started with the octopus salad and edamame.  I liked how it wasn't overly salty.  We had a few slices of sashimi and we had several rolls: the Dragon, Rainbow, the Chicago Spicy Crazy, the Winter, and the Summer.  All of them were delicious!  I had to say my friend had the best descriptions - "the Summer Roll was like running through a field in the summer time" and "the Chicago Spicy Crazy Roll was like a skyscraper in my mouth"  I loved the shape of this one too in a triangle.  To top this all off the place is BYOB, and the prices are phenomenal.  I don't remember a roll being more than $12.   The staff there was so accommodating in adding people to our group and bringing extra chairs, plates, etc.  It's like coming home where your  mom just knows what to do.  Even as we were the last people to leave the restaurant after it closed and they were cleaning, the lady stepped out to take a picture of all of us.  What a sweetheart!

When I crave sushi this always ends up being the place I go.  It is consistently fresh and has great tasting sushi.  I don't have the greatest knowledge of fine sushi, so as long as the stuff tastes "normal" it will be fine with me.  I usually look for inexpensive places that have edible sushi and decent variety, and this meets all those criteria. If you are a sushi purist or like the more rare varieties, you won't like this place as much.  Plus, as is often the case, seating is difficult to come by on Fri/Sat nights.

This is going to be a hard review to write since it is close to lunch now and all I want to do is eat the sushi at Green Tea. I went on a recommendation from my best friend.  We got there early around 6 on a Friday night.  Which was a good idea since the seating there is limited.  However we were seated quickly.  We brought two bottles of wine since this is a BYOB. The sushi was amazing.  I cant remember exactly what we got (blame it on the wine) but it was probably spicy salmon and tuna...and one speciality roll that was amazing (maybe the Chicago crazy?) The fish was excellent and the prices were reasonable.  For four rolls plus a seaweed salad, it ended up being around $24.00 (before tip) I cant wait to go back.  I would recommend going with just one other person as they have limited seating and only a few four person tables.

BYOB.  Please don't go to Green Tea because I don't want to compete with you for a seat at the bar.  After I went here once this summer, I became a regular.  Bob at Naniwa wanted to know what happened to me.  I had been going there for 10 years at least, and one visit to Green Tea and I knew I was done.  The fish is better, the prortions are generous and its about a dollar less a piece.  When you eat as much sushi as I do, that adds up.  No plastic green leaves at Green Tea - its fresh endive - even the garnishes rule.  If you are looking for playful banter from sushi chefs, Green Tea is not for you - the head chef is all business.

While it's situated close to Sushi Para II with the "all you can eat" special, Greentea offers much better sushi for less. Plus, you won't have to pick out all the extra rice. The restaurant itself is quite small, but perfect for groups of 2-3

My favorite sushi in Chicago.  It's cheap.  It's incredibly tasty.  It's not fast.  If you order during a busy streak, expect to wait an hour for your sushi to be ready. Thinking of eating there?  Think again - the service is slow, slow, slow.  Better to just get your sushi to go and eat in a park or at home. Still, it's cheap and delicious and you really can't ask for more.  Easily the best sushi in Lincoln Park.

This is by far the worst sushi I have ever had. Went there tonight for dinner after it was recommended by people from work. We ordered the shumai, 4 rolls and 2 pieces of red snapper sashimi. The shumai were ok but the dipping sauce tasted like bbq sauce which was totally unappetizing. The fatty tuna roll was very small (think diameter of a quarter). The other 3 rolls we had were just ok. The worst part was that of the pieces of red snapper sashimi, mine had a bone in it!!! I have never experienced that at a sushi restaurant before and I was thoroughly disgusted. I could not enjoy the rest of the rolls we were eating because I was constantly trying to feel if there were any bones in the fish. The waitress was awful. Constantly grunting responses to our questions and shoving things around our table. DO NOT EAT HERE.

Fantastic sushi.  The fish is always fresh and the cuts are generous.  Their salmon and tuna sashimi is top notch.  Also, as others have mentioned, some very yummy rolls, which are neatly put together.  The rice is perfectly prepared as well - not too sweet, but just the right amount of rice vinegar.   The place it very small and they are closed on Mondays!!!  What's up with that???  Their delivery service is prompt and careful.  A fantastic find.

So don't laugh, but I had never had sushi before. Not a fan of fish to begin with and the raw fish concept...I just was afraid.  Green Tea is a cozy little place and I loved sitting at the bar (watching the sushi chefs work their magic). I took the easy way out and had my boyfriend order for me. I had the California rolls and the spider rolls. So amazing, I couldn't stop eating! I left the restaurant feeling ready to explode with delicious goodness. And for someone who normally doesn't eat seafood, that's saying a lot!!!

Green Tea is a decent BYOB sushi option on Clark.  Good for a group of 2-3 people since it's tiny inside and there are only a few tables.  No reservations; it is hit or miss for a weekend wait.     They have a nice maki selection at a reasonable price.  I am a fan of the dragon, rainbow and spicy scallop rolls.   Dine in service is pleasant but can get a little crazy.  Even on the weekend it's usually one server working frantically to take care of all the tables on top of dealing with constant phone calls for take-out.   I've also had good experiences with their carry out service.  It's a good compromise when you're not in the mood to eat out and that Lean Cuisine that's been in your freezer so long its turned to a block of ice is so not calling your name.   Minus a star because sometimes the sushi can be too warm for my liking...not because it isn't fresh, but because they are so busy I don't think the fish gets back in the chilled section from maki to maki.

I definitely did not expect the sushi to be extremely good, but it was! I'm sold even though I'm sure the place can probably only seat 20 people and be packed. It was definitely cheaper than all the other sushi places i've been to in Chicago and it's well worth to just try it out and see if you like it. I really liked their Dragon Roll, Spider Roll, Chicago Crazy Roll, Spicy Tuna (i usually don't order this but it was great) and their Summer Roll (GREAT) off of their special menu. For 3 people the bill was only 52 bucks. BYOB!!

This is a great sushi bar if you are looking for regular sushi. The portions are very generous, and the fish is always very fresh. Sometimes difficult to get seated because very popular, but well worth the wait.

Green Tea always has great quality, fresh fish for a very reasonable price. They might not be the most adventerous/creative, but they nail the standards for a sushi joint.  that said, take out is best. the place is tiny, and the "service" is nil. Still, the sushi is so damn good i had to give it 4 stars - i eat there despite the angry waitress!

Easily my favorite sushi restaurant in the city. The price matrix wins again. I always get the Chirashi don which is wonderful because they add all those oshinkos and roes..yum! Best bang for thy buck (IMO). Not only this, I LOVE the sushi chefs. They are very hospitable, almost as if you are entering into their house. Getting to know them through sitting at the counter, they gave me great tips for my honeymoon in their native country. In addition, cutely enough - they showed me their translator to teach my words to say there. How much better can service get than that?

Ok after having a TERRIBLE time at another sushi restaurant (cough...Tsuki), my bf convinced me to try sushi again. Side note...I am an avid sushi eater, but I had such a bad experience that I needed time to heal (the fish was just BAD at that other place) . We grabbed a bottle of our nicest (cheapest) white wine and jumped in a cab.  Once we got to Green tea I was very hesitant, but I couldn't be scarred forever.  I started ordering some easy rolls.  Ok, those went down nicely.  I ordered some other rolls and they were all tasting great. I even ordered a few pieces of sashimi and they all melted in my mouth!  I WAS CURED!  Sushi once again made me happy like it did before that horrible time. Green tea is a great place to go because the sushi is good and it's byob.  The place is a little small though, so I wouldn't recommend going with more than 1 or 2 people.

This is hands down one of the smallest sushi houses I've ever been to!  It's so small that you should call it a sushi ROOM!  They do a ton of take-out business with people who live nearby.  If you can get a table and eat in, bring your own wine or beer or whiskey.   For the excellent quality of their fish, Green Tea is very affordable and as good as any swanky sushi house in Chicago.  It's not like the places with the trip-hop "trying to be a club" atmosphere.  It's not the overrated Tsunami.  It's more of a friendly neighborhood sushi house.  If you want a trendy atmosphere, this isn't for you. What's so memorable about Green Tea?  The spicy tuna salad!  It's a must try!  The raw nigiri/sashimi is always fresh and the maki reliable and awesome.  And, where else in the city can you get awesome Tekka or Sake Don for $12.95?  Ummm, actually, methinks maybe Ringo.

absolutley delicious maki and sashimi. everything was really authentic. In Japan all restaurants/cafe's are generally very small and food is presented to you with great detail and finish. Green Tea Sushi seemed to mirror that authenticity for a very, very reasonable premium that you can only find in the upper tier sushi restaurants like nobu and kaze. try the mirogai clam and the sweet ebi sashimi. you will not be dissapointed :)

One of my new favorites! We came at around 8:30pm on a Wed and almost all the tables were full, we choose to sit at the sushi bar. It's nice, you get to see the chefs in action and get to see all the sushi that other people order. I was constantly asking, "What's THAT?". We had four rolls - Spider roll, Jackie roll (my favorite of the bunch), Chicago Spicy Crazy, and a Crunchy roll (special). They were all super tasty and were wonderfully presented. Our bill came out to be $40 for two people.  The really good: Very reasonable prices, friendly staff, traditional and creative rolls, and FRESH sushi. The not so good: Parking on Clark St. (oye!) and its really cozy inside (4-5 tables only!) The verdict: The lunch specials and nigiri look like good values and I will definitely be back for more!

Easily in my top three list of sushi restaurants, Greentea never disappoints.  Two friends and I started with Sushi B combo (8 pieces), a Rainbow roll, and a Caterpillar roll before finishing off the meal with Philly and Ebi Kyo rolls.  That was enough for the three of us and the bill came to just under $50.  Not many seats are available so I prefer to go at non-peak times to avoid a long wait.

Delicious sushi at a reasonable price and it's BYOB. Yes, the place is tiny and the service can be slow but it's worth it. For a more relaxed experience, go for lunch. They have sushi/maki lunch specials for $7 - $12 that include miso soup.  I've been there a few times for lunch and it's never very busy, even on Saturdays. My GF loves the Chicago Crazy Spicy roll.

The absolute worst service I have ever experienced in Chicago. We waited over an hour and a half for 3 out of the 4 things we ordered.  The sushi is definitely not worth the wait.  Maybe try ordering take out?

Hands down, one of the best sushi places in Lincoln Park. There is no seating -- maybe 5 or so tables -- so you don't go here for the atmosphere or ambiance. It's purely for the delicious, delicious sushi! Most of the time I get take out, although will go in and eat if it's not too busy. There is no corking fee, which is nice. Their specialty rolls and maki are fantastic. I'd recommend the Chicago Crazy Spicy and the Caterpillar. For regular rolls, you can't really go wrong with any of the choices. Call ahead if you crave takeout -- they are usually packed inside and take around 45 mins to an hour on a Saturday night for takeout. Edit: I've done it -- eaten everything on the menu at least once!

FANFUCKINTASTIC SUSHI sure it's tiny, and the service can be a bit slow - but if you're smart and you make sure to order A LOT as soon as you are seated, then you will be fine. they don't bring it out all at once, we got our rolls in 3 groups, i really liked that because a) the tables are super small so it wouldn't have all fit and b) it ensured the freshness of the sushi Always get the special item that they advertise on the table - it's worth it! myself and 3 others shared the following: - the special: a fatty tuna roll (insanely good) - the crunchy roll (tempura-battered and deep-fried- awesome!) - spider roll (excellent) - rainbow roll (a different take on the usual, not my fav, but tasty) - 2 spicy tuna rolls (best i've ever had!) - spicy salmon roll w/cucumber and avocado (my friend who's been here the most says you can just tell the server what you want in a roll and they'll make whatever you ask for! AWESOME!) 7 rolls for 4 people (one who eats like a bird) - we finished it all plus a bottle of wine, and we were stuffed! the bill was around $20 per person including tip, i think it was around $60+ total. the rolls range from $2.50 - $12 depending on how much and what kind of fish they contain, but most are in the $3-$6 range. If you're going, call ahead and they will hold a table for you, otherwise be prepared to wait! check out my blog  barredowl.wordpress.com  for more of my opinions of Chicago restaurants/bars/other locales

Greentea is my #1 spot for sushi delivery. The sushi is really good and so reasonably priced! The california rolls have real crab in them and they are huge (8 pieces instead of 6). I also really like the shrimp tempura roll and spicy tuna maki. The only complaints I have is (1) every time I call for delivery they put me on hold for at least 5 minutes before taking my order, and (2) it always takes the max time to deliver the order. So if they tell you 1 hour - it'll be 1 hour. Overall I say that the good food and prices compensate for the bad service.... at least for delivery!

The sushi here is flat out awesome, and the price is nice (we stuffed ourselves on sushi and it was only $26 for 2 people!). Very small, but get a counter seat and watch the three sushi chefs in action. This place does a lot of take out, so you get to see all kinds of examples of their art. I had the Red Snapper, Freshwater Eel, Striped Bass, and Smoked Salmon sushi, it was so fresh, it seemed to melt in my mjouth. My wife had a bunch of vegetarian maki, and the black mushroom maki was about the best, although the sweet gourd and avacodo selections were very good as well. Only one maki was disappointing, and I suggest you steer clear. It involved cuumber, mint, and plum puree and although it sounded interesting, it just tasted really weird. Service was kind of inattentive as well (but nice and down to earth), even though its a small place. But these small quibbles aside, we'll be back, and we'll pass by places like Coast on the way here and laugh and laugh at the suckers paying twice what we did for inferior sushi and stuck up service .
Insanely affordable vegetarian maki, very cute-tiny space.  The value is HUGE and so are the portions.  Delicious food; welcoming sushi chefs...makes for perfect in-and-out lunch.

Total hole in the wall, no frills joint.  But the food!  So good and you won't believe how far your dollar goes.  The portions are big on everything but the seaweed salad, which tasted great, but compared to the other great deals on the menu just seemed overpriced.  I love that its BYOB and the staff is super friendly.

Don't be fooled by the Thai speaking Sushi Chefs, this place very tasty.  It seems a bit unassuming in a small store front on Clark and it is.  I hesitate to even write a review because it is already crowded enough.  There are few tables and about 6 seats at the bar. It is BYOB and the chefs love when you share.  The have some extremely interesting rolls and your standard fair.  I love octopus and this is the only restaurant I have ever been to that is able to create a tasty roll using that as the base.  Usually, I have to just get it as nagiri, sashimi or a salad.  They have also had a special Super Tuna roll for a while that is great. Hands down the Shrimp shumi appetizer is best I have ever had and Greentea is worth checking out just for those. The fish is fresh and the staff is friendly.   They have moochi and a great Japanese custard that you have to ask for special. Totally different atmosphere then your higher end joints like Tsunami and Tsuki but tasty just the same.  If you are looking for tasty, friendly eats without breaking the bank, Green Tea is the spot. They do pick up orders but I don't think they deliver.  One of Lincoln Parks best kept secrets, don't miss out. RrL

"See you tomorrow!!!" Probably my favorite sushi in the city because it tastes fresh, has a great variety of rolls with several different sauces and it is very friendly.  It costs roughly half as much as the trendy joints.  It is also BYOB.  Crunchy roll, fried tofu are great!

I was so excited to try this place especially after what I read from all of you yelpers and my neighbors, but maybe we went on an off day.  My BF and I got the salmon and then several rolls and they were just okay.  Actually the pieces of salmon were thick and hard to bite through.  I am very sad as we live near this establishment, but I think we will stick to our beloved Sai Cafe!
No question one of the best sushi places I have experienced in Chicago. Quaint setting, good service, great prices, and fresh melt in your mouth rolls. Try the summer roll. Yum.

Awesome ! Awesome ! Awesome ! I eat here atleast once a week - spicy tuna 'n shrimp tempura being my favorites. This place is good, and yes can get crowded -so takeout is the best option. Don't expect awesome service or ambience for the price they offer sushi ! The chefs are a nice happy bunch!
Nothing will blow you away but it's the best hole in the wall place for sushi when it comes to consistency.

Simple. Tasty. Fresh. GOOD. The dining area is small, usually filled with a line during rush peak times and best off doing take out or delivery as it is not far from Lincoln park or the lake where a nice picnic could be did and parking in the area is what you expect in an area with more apartments than parking spots. BYO from what i remembers, and Good.

This is my FAVORITE sushi spot in the City.  It looks like a hole in the wall, and I usually would not want to eat raw fish from a hole in the wall...believe me, but the sushi is the most fresh I have found!  I LOVE their jellyfish - it's the best!   You can carry out or order in.

Adorable presentation (caterpillar rolls with antennae! so cute!), somewhat slow/cranky service, solid but unremarkable taste sensations.  Made the mistake of coming with a group and waited for 458 years or so for a table; our own fault, but still sad. Also, a bit creeped out by the kitchen-adjacent bathroom, despite general cleanliness thereof.

I echo the sentiments of everyone on here.  The sushi is very reasonable, fresh and the rolls were outstanding.  The max capacity of the restaurant (per fire code) is 22, so there's not a lot of wiggle room.  And there was one waitress for the entire restaurant.  We waited quite a while before being greeted and served (even though we were very hungry).  The pieces were fresh and flavorful, the rolls were hand-crafted with care and melted in my mouth.  The BYOB only enhanced the experience...I would definitely love a seat at the sushi bar next time, to see the chefs taking time to create their masterpieces.  The service was the only thing that left anything to be desired, but I can't fault the waitress.  She looked very frazzled and stressed from having to deal with a full restaurant of customers, take-out orders walking in, serving as hostess and all the telephone calls.  Definitely worth a trip to check out.

Fresh, Fresh, Fresh. Is there a better compliment for a Sushi Restaurant. Oh, also nice sized portions, wonderful and innovative Maki Rolls, and very reasonably priced. Service is superb, with the multiple expert Sushi Chefs (usually at least 3) serving the small (read quaint and comfortable) restaurant of only 7-8 tables. And, they are always friendly and helpful. Best of all it's BYOB.
Delcious sushi, no-frills atmosphere and service.  You don't go here for the atmosphere.  It's just a simple place with good food.  BYOB helps keep the bill even lower. "SEE YOU TOMORROW!"

Stumbled upon this place last night and very glad we did. Complimentary miso soup. Nice. Spicy tuna and spicy salmon rolls. Good presentation. Excellent tastes. The scallops were delish and both rolls not overly spicy (sometimes the spice overpowers all the tastes - not the case here!). And it was all very fresh. Sweet little spot. I'd say there are 25 or so seats. Maybe less.  We sat at the counter (the only thing available) and really enjoyed watching the sushi chefs work their magic! Next time I'm in the 'hood and craving sushi, I wouldn't hesitate to come back.

Oh Green Tea...I love you.  You're so small and cute but your sushi is so reasonably priced and delicious.  I will never order in from another sushi place.  If you can snag one of the two tables in the restaurant it's BYOB and the servers are lovely.

My only 5 star rating (so far). My favorite place for sushi in the city. It's just really really really really really really really really really super duper good. Never disappointed by any item I've ordered. And it's pretty cheap. My recommendations include: (cooked) shrimp cucumber salad, spider roll (soft shell crab), spicy california, and the spinach roll.
